Posted: September 1, 2014
												I just finished my first playthrough of this game and I'm so moved that I barely have words to describe it. The story brought me to tears. The world and puzzles are whimsical in a way similar to the "magical thinking" of a child. The music is unique (South American wind instruments!) and perfectly captures the mood of the story. This game challenged my existing notions of storytelling through gameplay, with an emotional depth and complexity I've really never seen before in a game. Not only just a great game, but a fantastic human story. Just a whole other level of amazing.

Posted: August 9, 2014
												This game is criminally underrated.It stands side by side with another one of my favorite games Brothers: Tale of Two Sons as a shining example that a game can be fun as well as tell a beautiful story and have as much emotional resonance as any other type of art.The theme of this game is so dark but is approached in such a beautiful way that the ending left me in tears.And the game, though short (although I think the length is just right), has the right amount of difficulty.The art direction was also wonderful.  I loved how the favela was not something you just navigated through but was integral part of the game.I wish more people would play this.More games should be like this.

Posted: July 31, 2013
												Papo & Yo is a nice game with some shortcomings.The gameworld is beautiful, it feels like exploring a wonderfully imaginative daydream full of magical portals and walking houses.The fantastic soundtrack adds a lot to that atmosphere.The game is a bit disappointing when it comes to actual gameplay, though: It has platformer and puzzler elements but fails to really convince in either field.The platformer parts of very straightforward jumping over rarely more than three blocks, for most puzzles it's simply enough to press all buttons and levers available. Both game elements are so easy, there's hardly any challenge in the game. Additionally the jumping is very boring. Quico, the game's protagonist, doesn't jump very high and the double-jump ability he gets during the game makes him only jump slightly farther, not higher. In my opinion the game designers wasted a lot of potential: Making the gameworld more open and giving Quico tthe ability to jump on top of most buildings to explore the surreal city and adding some collectibles to find would have allowed to really take advantage of the amazing setting.Papo & Yo is rather short, according to Steam it took me about 3 hours to finish and I didn't rush through it. There are collectibles to find but out of a strange design choice they are only collectable after finishing the game at least once. I could definately see myself replaying some levels in order to get collectibles I missed but not the whole game (however short it is), especially as I already found a lot of the places where those collectibles appear the first time but couldn't pick them up then.All in all Papo & Yo is probably more a piece of art than a game. If you can enjoy a game for its beautiful scenery and music alone than I highly recommend to get this (but maybe wait for a sale).

Posted: November 22, 2016
												Super organic use-switches-to-move-blocks puzzler (this is a serious over-simplification) that is a metaphor for a man's story of how he dealt with a troubled childhood. The clue is in the dedication right at the start of the game. I don't want to explain too much about what is actually going on with this game because it takes the form of a "reveal" story that you see more of as it progresses. I can only say that the game mechanics and asthetics are very original and unique and that you feel a sense of wonder from the start. I would recommend it purely on merit of its originality but aside from that it's actually fun to play and thoroughly absorbing. If you are on the fence about getting it I would suggest a very quick look at a let's play or just someone who is playing it to see how interesting the mechanics are but, of course, it would be better if you don't resort to this and just jump in and experience it firsthand.*edit* in fact you can see some of how it works on its store page videos - which I luckilly didn't look at until after I played the game.

Posted: December 10, 2014
												Papo & Yo is a short (but very intense) puzzle adventure that turns around the struggle of a boy named Chico, as he explores an imaginary world (to eventually find a cure for the "monster", which clearly represents his father). This game develops a story about a theme that's obviously not the most feasible one, but it does so in a way that almost shock you (in a positive way).The gameplay could be described as a first person puzzle but there's so much more to it, in terms of colours (this game has some of the best colour palettes i've seen in a videogame), sound and interaction with the environment, within most of the levels your role will be to literally shape the space around you in a way that will let you solve the puzzles and move ahead. In some ways this feels as a "metagame", in a sense that it challenges you to go after preconceptions, no matter whether they're related to space or to what the space stands for. I would *strongly* encourage everyone to play this game. There isn't possibly not much of a age limit or any interest span that should stop you from playing.

Posted: August 7, 2013
												An adventure/puzzle-platformer that's light on challenge but heavy on quality story-telling. Excellent presentation and beautiful Latin American-themed artwork/music make Papo & Yo both a visual and audible pleasure. While the puzzles aren't anything that'll test your mind, it's less about figuring out how to solve them and more about watching and admiring the solutions as they unfold. The way you can manipulate the world with the push or pull of a lever is a neat sight to behold and has a "child-like imagination" feel to it. There are a few technical issues present (noticeable framerate drops here and there), but nothing significant.Overall, an impressive game that does a great job of using metaphors and symbolism to tell a powerful story full of dark subject matter in an accessible manner. Short, but still well worth playing.

Posted: May 23, 2014
												The colors and magic of the world of children, tainted by the darkness and harsh reality of the adults. I will not dwell on what happens in the game, as some might consider that to be spoiler territory.On the gameplay side, this is a puzzle game where reality bends and changes at will, leading to a sense of magic and surreality that is extremely pleasing. For thoses who don't like to think too much about puzzles, there are always hints to guide you, if you ever need them. They are optional, so you're never forced to read a hint if you don't want to. On the whole the puzzles are a bit like Portal : you stop for a while trying to figure it out, and then you have an ha-ha moment and manage to move forward. So not complicated, but give you just enough pause to make it satisfying to solve it.I really enjoyed the game, but got slightly frustrated toward the end. The game almost overstays its welcome. The goalpost keeps moving forward, you often think "this is it, i'm gonna see the ending", but there is actually one more puzzle to solve, and then another one, etc...Still on the whole the game is short enough for its own sake, and it's really worth to go through all of it to see the well crafted ending, and understand exactly what the game was all about.

Posted: November 1, 2014
												An interesting Indie platformer/adventure game with only a few minor things that set it back. I have to say it does remind me a lot of what Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons does in terms of story, conveying most of it through the gameplay and what you see rather than dialog, but this game does have dialog occasionally so its a little more clear sometimes what is going on. Even then though this game isn't what it seems like at first, without ruining it you will find out what the real theme is about and the metaphor for the monster as you go through.You play as a kid, Quinco who comes across at one point a big monster, who has an unhealthy appitite for poison arrow frogs and a very bad temper; he eventually becomes your companion on the story as well as your little robot protector Lula. You are following a strange girl who claims you are "cursed" and are on a journey to find out what is going on, and where you really are. Through out you need to platform and solve puzzles to progress through the areas of the game, many revolving around the monster himself. There are no real boss fights to speak of in the game.The game has some pretty good looking visuals, nothing that is going to push your machine to its limits but its very nice and the world itself very interesting and somewhat surreal at times. The game also has some fantastic music in it to go along with the visuals and perfectly fits the tone of the game and what is going on.The game controls fantastically with a controller and KB+M, however despite the game implying you to use a controller, I personally at least found it to play better and be more enjoyable with keyboard and mouse, so the port gets that right. In terms of perfromace there really isn't much to complain about, there are certain times where the frame rate will drop but quickly goes back.The issues with the game unfortunatly come from the design itself: while it is part puzzle game, the puzzles themselves aren't very challenging and are very itterative and repetitve, on top of that the game is short, very very short. Four hours is the most you can expect out of it, that's on first playthrough, but given how linear it is on subsequent playthroughs and knowing what to do, you could get through it in under three potentially. There is little incentive to replay the game too, outside of 25 hats hidden around the game to find, of which unlocks upon beating the game the first time. Besides that there are no other kind of collectibles or distractions, the puzzles, gameplay and story are the only attraction here.The story attempts to be emotional and moving, which it does pull off many times, but at the same time once you learn certain things it kind of falls apart and become predictable and that hold it has wears off, doesn't ruin the game though by any means.Overall, its a short, very easy, but enjoyable adventure through an interesting world and is charming at the same time. Its definatly worth playing through at least once, maybe twice if you are interested in collecting all the hats and achivements, but I cannot say I would recommend it at full price, but consider that part at your own discretion. All that said I did enjoy this game and I do recommend checking it out. None of the minor issues I mentioned are enough I think to deter from this nice puzzle/platformer.

Posted: September 30, 2014
												I don't normally write reviews for games I play. Once I finished them, I just go onto the next, but this game is not like the rest. I finished this game a couple of days ago and it's still lingering in my head. The story is unlike anything else in the industry. Rarely do games have the brass to tackle social issues such as alcohol abuse. This one does it in spades and leaves you feeling empty and melacholy inside. It's such a simple story with minimal dialogue, yet one of those plots that is told more through actions than words. I can't get into the story too much without spoiling it, all I can say is that this is a beautiful little gem among a vast Steam roster that is easy to sweep under the rug, but no one should ever miss one. Coupled with an equally beautiful and mesmerising soundtrack to go along with the moving and emotionally driven plot, if there is any example proving games can be art, it's Papo & Yo.

Posted: June 16, 2016
												A beautiful game in every meaning of the word.Aesthetically Papo & Yo is so beautifully designed and rendered that it almost needs nothing else to recommend it. But then it brings so much more to the experience.This is a game that has me writing - and erasing - and re-considering - and re-writing. This game is simply that powerful.At GDC2015 I spoke about the power of games to engage - and change - minds and Papo & Yo is one of the games that I used as an example. The relatively simple narrative is transformed when combined with the game mechanics into something very powerful: Papo & Yo reveals the ability of games to be something much more.This is not to say that the narrative and associated emotions will necessarily speak to everybody, but if they do then: watch out. Although I've finished the game, I only have around half of the achievements and don't plan on returning to the game. As beautiful and engaging as it is - the emotional impact is something that, although I am glad I experienced it, cannot go through again.(If you ever hear an art / movie / book critic scoff about "games as art" ask them to play this game. The interactive nature of digital games offer an emotional experience like no other medium.)

Posted: July 27, 2014
												More disclosure from me. I may be the world's worst platform puzzle gamer. I am absolutely terrible at these things. So going into "Papo y Yo" I was a little hesitant but the great reviews and the relatively short gameplay time had me thinking "why not". "Papo y Yo" is the story of a boy named Quico dealing with an abusive alcoholic father. While hiding in the closet he sees a chalk mark on the wall and ends up falling into a dream like world and for the next 3-4 hours you'll be traversing this world in order to find someone or something to help you cure the Monster (AKA your father's demons). I really enjoyed this game. The game world was incredibly cool and the soundtrack was excellent. The gameplay is standard puzzle platforming but other than a couple frustrating moments this wasn't difficult at all, even for a rank amateur like me.  Some might take issue with the game length but I found it perfect. The pacing was excellent and there wasn't a lot of time wasted. The game wasn't perfect. I did come across a bug or two that would screw up a couple of jumps here and there and the gameplay variety was a little lacking (pulls this, push that etc.). Some may also find the game a bit pretentious (the monster = Quico's dad, frogs = alcohol) but it didn't bug me at all and I found "Papo y Yo" to definitely be a journey worth taking. 8=10 from me.

Posted: March 12, 2014
												I wish Papo & Yo was the first game I've ever played.There's something about it which envokes a childlike wonder within players - the entire game is reminiscent to an interactive Pixar experience, the feelings we used to have as kids watching Toy Story or Monsters Inc. This lies in the wonderfully magical aesthetic of the game - the colours are vibrant, the music is playful, and the world feels magical, displaying a beautiful level of imagination.At its core, Papo & Yo is a third person puzzle platformer, but I would never dare use this as a description for this game. The puzzles are all very well paced, providing the slightest challenge, which although may be offputting to some, the previously mentioned magic within the world makes up for it. Quico (the main character of the story), the young boy who travels inside his own imagination will be picking up boxes and causing houses to move on little legs. He will make staircases pop out of the side of houses, or rotate a building inside of itself to reveal a new path to further advance in his goal. Each time I found myself with a new interaction in the environment, my eyes lit up with glee as the Pixar effect of discovery, imagination and beauty played off on screen. Quico is accompanied by three other characters; Lula, Monster and Alejandra. Lula is Quico's helpful pet/toy robot. She rides attached on his back, constantly hugging him and allowing Quico to do a double jump thanks to her rocket booster legs. Lula can also be used to flip switches out of Quico's reach. Alejandra is the first character we meet, and the only one we don't really get to interact with. She is a metaphor for Quico's growth throughout his journey, and not much can be said about her without spoilers.Lastly, there's Monster. A giant, fat, bulky, horned creature who either sleeps, eats, or looses himself in rage attacking anything in sight. He brings a majority of the puzzle elements in the game, as Quico has to manouver Monster via the usage of fruit, which Monster loves and will run up to one if he sees one, in order to advance to the next area. Monster also loves to eat frogs, but upon doing so he will enter a state of rage, charging at Quico and attempting to kill him.This brings me into the game's strongest point - the story.The story in Papo & Yo is based on real-life experiences of it's director amd designer Vander Caballero. The Monster is a metaphor for an alcoholic and abusive father, and the world Quico finds himself in is his imaginary escape, picturing his father as Monster. Without spoiling much, you will understand the effect and impact of this metaphor especially towards the last 20/30 minutes of this game.The game is rather short, as displayed on my profile it took me just three hours to beat, but I also haven't had the chance to explore every nook and cranny to find the collectible "hats" in game. When considering Papo & Yo, please don't let it's length turn you off the game. It is a beautiful, heart-touching, childlike experience unlike any other I've seen in video games so far. Due to Papo & Yo's easy difficulty, no deaths or death penalty, a story which is well suited for everyone - children will love the aesthetic; the characters; the environments; the puzzles, whereas older audiences will love the metaphor and the meaning behind the game, I simply have to recommend this game to everyone.TL;DR: Beautiful aesthetic, very deep and emotional story, envokes childhood memories and feelings 10/10 recommended for everyone.

Posted: June 23, 2014
												While this game took me only 4.8 hours to complete, I was incredibly pleased with the experience. It had just the right amount of semi-challenging puzzle solving and engaging story. The story is really what shines here, and the atmosphere and soundtrack really drag you into it. It's difficult to comment on without giving spoilers, but I will say that even if you had an amazing childhood with great parents, you'll still find the story heartwarming.As far as the gameplay itself, don't expect anything too difficult. Most puzzle solutions revealed themselves in one to two attempts, and the platforming aspects were fairly easy, especially with a controller. This is not a game you'll be playing more than once, because once you see the story through to the end, there's nothing left. No replay value, but great first-play value.

Posted: December 30, 2014
												First time I was staring speechless at credits after a game. Before playing this game I assumed it would be a fun game for  kids with crazy moving houses, but I was wrong. Yes, I got moving houses and many more weird level design ideas (which on its own would make a great game), but the story blew my mind. It's not happy at all but bitter and sad. After getting attached to all of the characters, even a robot toy, I was close to tears when anything would happen to one of them. The ending was hard to finish, not because of puzzle complexity, but because of extreme emotional load.The only downside to game is how short it is, but I was not expecting anything longer.I would recommend it to anyone who likes weird level platformers, unusual characters and wants to experience a game that has a deeper meaning.

Posted: February 13, 2014
												This one is interesting.It has nice puzzles and seems very creative. There are many games that go for an "Art form" approach but I felt this game didn't quite nail it. Don't get me wrong it is a good game. I feel the story is new and emersive taking key parts of childhood and focusing on how imagination is a beauty. But as far as a story, this is just the cover. Inside i found the controls clunky and a suprisingly annoying checkpoint system. My character seemed a little slow, although this is just a speed preference, and the turning didn't help. At parts it felt like it was aesthetically finished but still like playing a early access game. I remeber one point I got very stuk on a level and used hints to try to figure it out. I had placed a box to get to  a higher platform and it hadn't worked. I watch a walk through and my box should have been two inches to the right and none of this was clearly marked outI know I have been quite mean during this review but on the whole it was still enjoyable. I would give it a 6/10

Posted: April 30, 2014
												I finished Papo & Yo last night. It joins "Brothers" on the short list of "beautiful games with fun and innovative mechanics and an ending that made my 4-year-old daughter cry lots."At Sony's giga-booth at E3 last year I saw a screenshot of a boy running up a path made of buildings lying down, but there was no indication of what game it was from, and I really wanted to play whatever it was, and I was happy to discover that it's from Papo & Yo (and that section is even cooler than that screenshot led me to hope it would be).

Posted: September 8, 2013
												I cannot recommend this game enough. It is a very special puzzle platformer full of childlike wonder that explores the effects of parental abuse. It is a beautiful, healing sort of game with a very emotional ending. It is very personal to me because it actually helped me to heal from my own childhood issues. This is a rare gem in the gaming world that you shouldn't pass up.

Posted: January 29, 2014
												Neat Indie game with an interesting back story. I bought it on sale for around 1 dollar, not the 15 that it normally is. Short story; I finished in about 3 hours. Also, the puzzles aren't very difficult at all. If you're going to play it, play it for it's artistic value-not gameplay.

Posted: December 28, 2013
												Man, the final chapter...... I've got surprised. There's a deep meaning to every character you see. A story behing on what you are facing in the game.This game is great. It's beaultiful, it's gorgeous, it's brilliant. At first, you think this game is just a simple and bealtiful game, but after the end, you may see a diferent perception of it. The puzzles are great and challenging. You always have a little hint if you need and it's incredibly fun to solve it ( even when you have to control the monster to not eat the freakin frog. God, that was annoying.... but fun ). I've never seen a game like that. It's just bealtiful, but as long as you keep playing, getting closer and closer to the end... the game becames darker and a bit deep. I don't think someone 'simple-minded' could handle the truth.I've got really touched at the credits. The music was just so...... I don't know what to say. It was a nice experience and definetly worth the money. But the end, the credits....... oh god.......

Posted: March 19
												K, not sure I have ever cried that much during a video game. Yeah the game is a metaphore for growing up with an alcoholic parent. I cringed, I cried, i raged, I felt so angry at times playing this game. And maybe i feel a little healed from it too. It was a very difficult emotional journey for me to get through. I didn't know that there was that much feeling and emotion hiddenin me that was brought to the surface by this game.

												Nice background music.Strange world.Amazing story.Child abuse, an usual issue, was told in a very unique and touching way.I loved the experience. It's worth to play !

Posted: December 30, 2014
												First time I was staring speechless at credits after a game. Before playing this game I assumed it would be a fun game for  kids with crazy moving houses, but I was wrong. Yes, I got moving houses and many more weird level design ideas (which on its own would make a great game), but the story blew my mind. It's not happy at all but bitter and sad. After getting attached to all of the characters, even a robot toy, I was close to tears when anything would happen to one of them. The ending was hard to finish, not because of puzzle complexity, but because of extreme emotional load.The only downside to game is how short it is, but I was not expecting anything longer.I would recommend it to anyone who likes weird level platformers, unusual characters and wants to experience a game that has a deeper meaning.

Posted: August 9, 2016
												.....Wow! What an experience. I wish I knew about this game sooner. The game primarily deals with a boy interacting with a big creature called 'Monster' as well as a guide and a toy robot friend. Although the game has been out for years, I won't spoil the story. I highly appreciate how well crafted it is in the game and how the devs want each person to interpret the story based on their experiences and perception.The music is great and adds to the atmosphere. I will say that I didn't like how there were some bad camera angles. And a couple puzzles were more based on precision and timing rather than just thinking puzzles. And it can set you back to the beginning of the puzzle. And there is a bit of backtracking so make sure you don't mind that.

Posted: July 12, 2016
												Papo & Yo was one of the best gaming experiences I've ever had. The gameplay, the soundtrack, the story, everything was just wonderful. As many have pointed out, this game deals with heavy themes of abuse and alcoholism told through the imagination of a young boy. This is another game that you can beat in one sitting, it takes about 3 hours. The puzzles aren't mind burners, but they're very engaging, varied and charming. It's a bit of an emotional rollercoaster if you're open to it, and I enjoyed every minute that I spent with it.

Posted: November 25, 2016
												The game harks back to when the only thing games had to really sell you on was a deep story.The puzzles and graphics are well rounded and pleasing, but the story and the revelations as you play through it is one of the best naratives I've played in many years.

Posted: November 23, 2016
												Such a great puzzle platformer game.  The real treat here is the story and setting.  Visually beautiful, using Brazil, specifically using Rio de Janeiro, and it's street art to perfection.  Then there is the story, learning that it is a parallel to the game creator's childhood relationship to his alcoholic, addicted, and abusive father is just emotionally a wave of feelings that by the end you may get a bit choked up.  I finished this on the PlayStation 3, but I had to get the Steam version because it's that good.

Posted: November 25, 2016
												A magical realism platform/puzzler with a largely symbolic plot that manages not to be heavy-handed.  You explore the city and use magical chalk drawings to manipulate the colorful environment.  Meanwhile, your character gets more and more bedraggled as he interacts with his friend, Monster.  Monster, alternates between a playmate and a villian/obstacle, depending on whether he has indulged his addiction to poisonous frogs.  Good, intuative controls and a sensible camera along with a thoughtful story make this platformer worth your time.

Posted: November 19, 2016
												This game was interesting to play throughout the whole story line. The mechanics and how things worked in the game made it for some difficult puzzles to figure out as well as some straight forward puzzles. Will most likely play the game through again.

Posted: May 11, 2014
												Papo y Yo is a textbook example of "Games as Art". In terms of gameplay, you won't get much and it's incredibly short; I beat it in less than 3 hours. However, the concepts/ideas and visuals are nice and there was one or two surprises that I didn't see until right before they happen. The development team is fairly creative and they do succeed in capturing child-like wonder and exposition though atmosphere, though that's their only major successes. The "big reveal" is blatantly obvious halfway through the game and it should have balanced more on the characters/backstory than just the message. My biggest complaint is that there is no real payoff to all the buildup; it kinda just sits unresolved and quite frankly, is unsatisfying. While that may have been the intention, the rest of the game isn't satisfying enough to justify leaving it that way. Overall, the game is simply "pleasant". Don't go out of your way to get this game, but if it stumbles upon you for cheap, it's worth a single afternoon.

Posted: May 5, 2014
												This game is a very touching story. The game is expansive, beutiful, captivating and inviting. There were a few times where you can feel you are stuck, but it doesn't matter, you'll figure it out. The soundtrack was done by Brian D'Oliveira, who is just a master at his trade. This soundtrack has real feeling in it, and adapts as you progress through the level, never did I feel as if the music was intrusive, or annoying, but a perfect compliment to the art and game style.  Papo & Yo has been awarded with over 10 different awards, all well deserved. If you have an afternoon, and want a game that is different than the norm, but very worth its price tag. You have found it.

Posted: November 22, 2016
												Super organic use-switches-to-move-blocks puzzler (this is a serious over-simplification) that is a metaphor for a man's story of how he dealt with a troubled childhood. The clue is in the dedication right at the start of the game. I don't want to explain too much about what is actually going on with this game because it takes the form of a "reveal" story that you see more of as it progresses. I can only say that the game mechanics and asthetics are very original and unique and that you feel a sense of wonder from the start. I would recommend it purely on merit of its originality but aside from that it's actually fun to play and thoroughly absorbing. If you are on the fence about getting it I would suggest a very quick look at a let's play or just someone who is playing it to see how interesting the mechanics are but, of course, it would be better if you don't resort to this and just jump in and experience it firsthand.*edit* in fact you can see some of how it works on its store page videos - which I luckilly didn't look at until after I played the game.

Posted: January 16, 2014
												Can't properly remember the last time i played something that good! Got a little "upset" to see this game didn't get much attention, but i'm glad i played - and i did really enjoy it - and i hope some you will play it too. Papo & Yo  is something between reality and dreams, hope and escapes, is a little story about a boy named Quico that suffered from his abusive, alcoholic father, and on this case the father is the "monster" that follow us. The father is really gentle, kind person, but when drinks get super violent, but on this case when the monster eats frogs - and by frogs we change for alcohol - will get very angry. About this 'masterpiece', with has a lot of puzzles, not very hard our to easy puzzles, medium puzzles that you can solve in 1/2 min, it also has a very good artistic side, in almost every corner you will see some graffiti with excellent art.  Although the favelas are always empty you can "sense" some loneliness but is also here some people are happy. The OST that follows is great, super calm, fits with the theme. Ths plot will suffer some huge twist, some happy twist and some SAD twist, and if you "connect" with the characters you will get a little sad - like i did - , but in the end is a explanation to all. With no doubt is a EXCELLENT game, everyone should play it and enjoy the most! Some of you will get some empathy - like me - but the story kind remember some people lives, so make a favor to yourself and play this! ~ 10/10

content:
Posted: May 5, 2015
												A beautiful and heart-wrenching game entrenched in metaphor. This game left me shocked, silent and with a lot of thoughts to process. Our story opens with Quico, a young boy living in a Brazillin favela with his abusive alcoholic father. Retreating into his imagination, we follow his adventures through a surreal landscape as he interacts with his friend Monster as his means of coping with the real world. Beautifully written and and powerfully executed, more than once I felt on the brink of being physically ill at many of the implications and how they related to Quico's life.In terms of gameplay, it's a fairly standard puzzle-platformer. As you travel through the favela you'll be pulling levers, hitting buttons, manipulating the landscape in surreal ways, and either coaxing Monster to aid you, or running from him. The puzzles are fairly simple and never frustrating, nor do they ever interfere with the game's atmosphere. In terms of music, the atmosphere is only boosted by a gorgeous soundtrack (which you can purchase along with the game). The game's only downfall is how short it is, as it can be completed in less than a day.This is truly a masterpiece and a work of art. If you're a fan of heavily story-driven games, I highly recommend Papo & Yo.

												This game only has simplistic gameplay and puzzles, but even in its simplicity, the small aspects of the game seem to paint brushstrokes on the canvas to completing a masterpiece. The imagery seen through the interactions between Papo & Yo is outstanding! It told a story that I wasn't expecting heading into this one. Halfway through, I finally realized why this game is called Papo & Yo.So TO BUY or NOT TO BUY:If you like shorter, artsy, puzzle games that have meaning behind them, then this game will probably be a good playthrough for you. However, if that's not your kind of game, then you'll probably find yourself bored within a couple of minutes. Overall though, I had a decent experience with this one and enjoyed it.My personal rating: 6.5/10See you on the other side,Godspeed!

content:
Posted: August 31, 2013
												Papo and Yo is well worth your time.Very novel, well executed and powerful subject matter. Papo and Yo is the culimination of a son's experiences with his drunken and abusive father.Dark stuff indeed, but Papo and Yo is very careful not to overplay its theme too hard.The game felt to me as if it were borrowing from Miyazaki's Spirited Away at times. A young protagonist trying to cope with circumstances far outside their control. Dark at times, but careful to not to burn you out, feeding you just a small piece of the darker story before dropping you back into lighter fantasy.The game features a lot of thought and consideration for the design of it's puzzles and mechanics. The platform elements are rarely frustrating. And, the game provides many shortcuts as you explore a given level to help you recover from bad jumps.This game is just a great bit of fun and has great payoff of its theme. Please give this one a play.

content:
Posted: July 21, 2013
												Papo & Yo ('Father & I') is a third person puzzle platformer and tells the story of Quico and his friend Monster, who has a prefernce for tasty frogs. Unfortunately, these frogs turn the calm Monster into a violent and dangerous creature, so Quico sets out to find a cure for his friend - but is there any?While this sounds like your average game story, it gains a lot of emotion and intensity once you realize that the story is metaphorical for Creative Director Vander Caballero's troubled childhood. It's relatively subtly tied into the game and if you don't pay enough attention or don't care about it, you could very well miss the message of the game, so don't rush it, step back for a moment and let the impressions work.The game has relatively simple platforming mechanics and you will mostly end up jumping over gaps to progress in the level. Due the general pace of the game, there hardly are any timed events where, for example, you have to press a button and then quickly run somewhere to move on.Relatively early into the game you also find your friend Lula, a toy robot who will latch onto your back and lets you double jump by launching his tiny jet pack. Additionally, you can also command him to flip switches that are out of your reach.While the puzzles present themselves in a unique and creative manner, they aren't really challenging at all and mostly just require simple combination skills. It's a shame because the puzzle design as such is wonderful and could've made for some fun challenges.Papo & Yo is based on the Unreal 3 Engine and while this engine isn't exactly the standard for visual fidelity these days, the game still looks pretty good and the lighting and level design add a lot to the overall atmosphere.With roughly 4 hours of playtime, the game is fairly short, but if the game would've been filled with repetative puzzles in favor of playtime, the emotion and strength of the story would have suffered immensively and would've made this game just yet another average puzzle platformer.There are dolls scattered throughout the levels and once you beat the game, those dolls will receive hats which you then can collect in a second playthrough. Other than that, the game doesn't provide you with anything else to do, which is fine - games like Papo & Yo aren't meant to be played for days, weeks or months. They want you to immerse yourself for a few hours, tell you a story and maybe even think about it a few days later.Papo & Yo is a prime example of how emotional and intense video games can be. Don't buy it for the platforming and don't buy it for the puzzles. Buy it for the story and let the emotions take over.

content:
Posted: August 6, 2013
												This may very well be the first example of magic realism in a videogame. More than a little rough around the edges, Papo & Yo still deserves enormous respect for its brilliant handling of metaphor, unerring focus on the strengths of the medium and other fancy concepts like that while managing to not be too snobbish and arty-wanky about it. Add painterly, enchanting visuals and culture-fusing music to that and you've got something quite unique on your hands.

content:
Posted: July 25, 2016
												Papo y Yo was a game that came out a while ago that I only now got around to playing despite having it since it came out on Steam. I'd been intrigued by it from the time the creator started talking about it, and interviews I saw on Giantbomb years ago now. The themes of an abusive father and alcoholism are things I am all to familiar with and so I found it intriguing that the creator wanted it to be the cruxt of the game.Unfortunately, as a game, there is really only one mechanic. It's a really cool mechanic, but there's only one. Terrain deformation. Basically you play Quico, a young boy, and you have to traverse this surrealist world to unfold a story. You move around buildings, change the terrain, create stepoping stones, all in the name of... fairly typical platforming. The game is very easy and never really gets difficult at all.Since this is the only mechanic there isn't really a time you should get stuck and even if you do it won't be for very long. The puzzles are super simplistic.Graphically the game is amazing. I have nothing, but praise for the visuals crafted for this adventure. The aspects of moving houses, terrain that bites down like teeth, or even just the backdrop of what appears to be Brazilian streets are all splendidly realized. Even the beautifully crafted murals which serve no purpose, but to make areas look cool. The one good thing I can say about this game is that it looks amazing. But a video game is not bought just to look at it. We want to experience it, and in that Papo y Yo fails entirely to create a worthwhile experience. As said previously mechanically the game has little to offer, and while novel for an hour or so it quickly wears thin. On top of that the story is abominable. In parts it's incredibly hamfisted- catering mostly to visual metaphor (the game is never explicit and yet is always entirely implicit) it's never not obvious what the story is talking about, and that is fine. Yet the way it gets to what I would assume is it's moral is entirely questionable and not something I agree with at all. It's telling that you play a child as the platitude at the end is comepletely childish.-Spoiler for the ending. Do not read further if you don't want to know.-I understand being abused as a child, and having a father who is an alcoholic, but to imply that there is nothing you can do about it, and you should just let them go forever is something you believe when you are a child but is not actually true. That's called giving up, and where I come from you never give up on family.There are many other aspects of the story I found completely nonsensical: such as monster as it is represented- a visual representation of his father- makes absolutely no sense. I am unsure if the creator understands how people work. There is always a reason people do bad things. They don't just do things. Anyway, I won't continue to go on and on about the creator of this game's world view. I wouldn't recommend believing it, though, as it's a good way to become everything you hate.I like the visuals in this game. They are often gorgeous, surreal, and amazing to see. Everything else in this game is completely skippable- right down to the terrible moral espoused at the end here. I do not recommend this game at all. If you want to see the cool visuals you can most likely look up pictures of the game and get the same effect. There's nothing else to experience here.

content:
Posted: June 18, 2014
												Papo & Yo is a truly excellent 3d puzzle platformer has great gameplay, great visuals, and a great story.The main gameplay sees you solving a series of puzzles using what's given to you by the environment. Each puzzle introduces some kind of mechanic and the 3D platforming gameplay gives you an interface to interact with that mechanic. Discovering what that mechanic does then figuring out how to manipulate it to progress is key and the game does an excellent job of letting you explore the mechanics without punishing you for trying something that doesn't work.  If you mess up, the game gives you a way to come back from what you've done and in the few cases where you can fail (such as falling off a cliff), you get put back in quickly so you can try again. This is a great way to encourage players to explore their options and try anything they can think of and is an example of how to do puzzles well. None of the puzzles are repeats, so each puzzle gives you something new to chew on without any filler. All of the challenges are really well designed and fun, while there were one or two puzzles that got a bit tedious, I wouldn't say any of them were unenjoyable. I did encounter one glitch where my character got stuck and couldn't move, but other than that everything was pretty solid.The graphics of this game are excellent both artistically and technically. Unreal Engine 3 is being used in full force to create a game that looks nothing short of gorgeous. The game uses lighting and bump mapping to great effect, but this would be mean nothing without the creative visuals that the developers put on display. The game more or less take place inside the protagonist's imagination (that's not a spoiler by the way), so they get really creative with the environments. The color pallete is vibrant and absolutely beautiful to look at. The animation of the monster is also fantastic, although the player character's run cycle felt a little bit stiff. Unlike most indie games that run on Unreal Engine 3, this game is actually extremely well optimized, and my GT 440 (which is somewhat old and outdated by now) usually got around 40 FPS on max settings.Even though the gameplay and graphics are fantastic, the story just might be the best thing about Papo & Yo. I won't go into too much detail because that would spoil it, but the storytelling does a great job of telling a deep, emotional story in a mostly nonverbal way. What you see in the imaginary world of the character's imagination is allegorical to his life (and the life of the creator of the game), which makes the game feel the developer is opening up a very personal part of his life to you. It's emotional and beautiful there are some soulcrushing twists along the way.Overall, Papo & Yo is a must-play for anyone interested in puzzle games or great stories.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 12, 2016
												Papo & Yo is not the first game developed in the story direction of childhood abuse or parental issues, though it is understandable that people with such experiences want to make stories with that focus.And that in a sense leaves me feeling uneasy about what I want to say for this game. It is the awkward borderline of judging a game for it being a game, and judging it for the overall intentions.Now, I know the review began with giving away the premise of the game, but the reason I was fine with doing so is because of an immediate flaw in the game. Within the actual first minute of Papo & Yo, right after starting a New Game, there is a dedication and following scene which give away the game's purpose. That destroys any surprise completely. I definitely think that the game should have been set up differently for an even stronger impact of the parallels/metaphorical world.Despite that, the game moved along properly story-wise with what the characters represent. And the general events that occur as well as the world's environment are very strong and unique because of how surreal things get. The graphics of the game are mostly well-done, with interesting setup of the favela you traverse, nice color for the world as it morphs around you. Towards the end of the game, some of the physical effects that happened to the map genuinely made me dizzy, which, while not exactly enjoyable, gave me the idea of how strongly I was grounded in the distorted world.As I said towards the beginning of the review, though, how I want to judge this game is not exactly balanced. Though I became quite invested in Quico (the main character) throughout a short game that took me less than 4 hours, that does not mean that the game was perfect by any means.In fact, the majority of the flaws were from its technicality as a game. The game is platforming and puzzle-solving. The puzzles as a whole were all extremely easy to find the solution to; but many were made simply annoying due to how you get around as well as the Monster's interactions. For instance, there are some places where the Monster is literally in rage, trying to hurt you, which is understandable for the story. However, due to your limitations, some of the puzzles with that end up taking a long time because the Monster easily catches you, can block your path and throw you around over and over, and so on. It's meant to be a challenge for some of the puzzles, but the ones where Monster is permanently angry tended to waste a lot of my time, instead of making me more sad for the child.Most of the puzzles for a good chunk of the game require the same repeated actions. Flip a switch here; run somewhere else and flip a few more; return to your original spot and flip the switch back. Grab this item; run away from the monster; throw it somewhere. The game didn't get that unique until some of the extremely surreal areas of the game, or the puzzles that allow you to move or attach favela houses to one another to create bridges and platforms.The platforming aspects of the game are also rather disappointing and need lots of cleanup. There are a lot of invisible boxes blocking you all over the place. Whenever I was climbing around or jumping across rooftops, for instance, I would very often find Quico hitting some invisible edge of the roof. Despite seeing his whole body being above it all, I would fall down and have to go back around. Or there were certain puzzles where I saw a way to physically reach an object or switch, but there was an invisible box floating in the air, intentionally preventing me from getting there. There's also graphical issues such as clipping, where Quico's body would be inside of a wall or through some object on the ground.There was also horrendous lag during certain puzzles, and also any time I would enter a new area or a checkpoint occurred. Literally, everything would just freeze up and move choppily for several seconds, until the game got itself together again. The frequency of this was quite bothersome, usually being every handful of minutes.In the end, there was a lot of disappointment for me in how Papo & Yo was a "game", in its playability. There is lots of frustration with technical glitches and certain bad puzzle layout to the point where it got me angry (which isn't common for me), when it should have only been the story evoking my emotions.Thus, I am on the fence in how to end this review. The point of the story is not exactly new, though the visual aspects and uniqueness of the world are interesting. The idea of the gameplay using Monster is also intriguing, though there are many issues as mentioned above.Since there is only a "Yes" or "No" in Steam, I guess I will give "Yes" a slight edge due to the world.

content:
Posted: January 20, 2014
												This masterpiece caught me off-guard.  I was expecting a lighthearted platforming romp through puzzles, like Portal, but instead what I got was a powerfully moving story.  The visual experience that is this game is hard to overstate.  The puzzles are unique and balance the edge between challenge and ease perfectly.  The dual-layering of everything you see and experience is really powerful, and merits a second playthrough, just to let what you're seeing sink in.What impressed me most about the game was the incredible imagination it showed.  It's so imaginative, you really do feel like you're controlling a creative child, without it feeling too much like a children's game.  Believe me, it isn't.  10/10, best game I've played in years.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 10, 2013
												Papo & Yo is the story of a boy who wants to save his friend Monster. On the surface this seems rather silly and simplistic, but it is a metaphor for a very real and heart wrenching tragedy. It is highly uncommon to see real world social issues brought up in games, especially social issues which no one wants to talk about, but Papo & Yo does this beautifully. The core gameplay is a puzzle platformer. The puzzles are quite easy to be honest, and if you get stuck it has a built in help system. The world you are in is very surreal and fantastical (think Salvador Dali), and is set in a bario neighborhood somewhere in South America. The soundtrack in this game is just fantastic as well. You must play this game to the end, or else it will not make much sense.  While this is certainly not the best game I have ever played, it is by far one of the most memorable. Papo & Yo takes about 3-4 hours to complete. 9/10Please upvote this review if you found it useful :)

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 4, 2013
												"Ba ha ha video games can't deal with any sort of real-world issues!""Yeah?  How about THIS!""Oh no I am undone!  HSSSSSS!"Papo & Yo is an extremely metaphorical game about a boy's relationship with his abusive, alcoholic father (I don't think that's really a spoiler, considering the trailer makes that fairly obvious), and it's based on the lead designer's own childhood experiences.  The game deals with the issue absolutely brilliantly.  It really perfectly conveys the mixture of love, fear, and pity Quico feels.  It's also a fantastic example of gameplay-story integration, one of the best I've played.  The gameplay of alternating between working with and running from Monster really makes you feel the themes, which wouldn't work in any other medium.  To top it off, the gameplay is actually quite fun, and the graphics and music are both gorgeous.  If you value games as a storytelling medium, play Papo & Yo.

content:
Posted: February 28, 2015
												The game starts out a bit slow but give it a go for at least 30 minutes and you'll start to see what got me hooked. This is probably one of the very few games I'll tell players to FINISH IT. PLAY IT TILL THE END.The game is short compared to other story driven games but you know what? It might be short but time well spent. Story telling in this game is subtle - it doesn't make any sense in the beginning but slowly everything will come together as you play. No plot twist, story just unfolds gradually and then BAM! Everything make sense at the end.The puzzle difficulty is just right for me, a couple of retries here and there but not to the point of throwing away my gamepad and bawling on the couch. Even if you're not the puzzle type of person, go play around with the puzzle and you'll be at awe at some of the designs. Manipulating buildings, terrain and my favourite - carrying big fat squishy frogs (I don't think anyone enjoy splatting the frogs though, they're too cute to be treated that way!)Another thing that's worth praising are the the tutorial and hint system are very well done - unobstructive upon request-only tutorial and subtle hints pointing you to the right direction without giving it all.If you're looking for a short, but meaningful game - this is the one.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												Papo and Yo originally invented for the PS3 is renowned for it's role as an empathy game. One of the few games on the market aimed specifically to evoke an emotional empathy response from it's player, this is largely because the developer Vander Caballero found here... http://www.weareminority.com/ has decided to use the expression of game art to exercise his own personal demons.While it was largely inspired by the game 'ICO' there is a more larger similarity to the game 'Among the Sleep' and 'Brothers' in the way that the developer has chose to use cute characters and backgrounds to handle some adult touchy subjects such as alcoholism and physical abuse.The story revolves around a young Brazillian boy named Quico who cowers in his bedroom closet while his father storms past. He then escapes into a magical slum world he creates where he finds a girl Alejandra who at first sees Quico as a threat, but who eventually aids him in his adventure. He is also joined by a robot toy named 'Lulu' which always has his back and a monster who is usually somewhat love-able who sleeps a lot and you can have fun bouncing off his belly, but when he ever has French Cuisine he launches himself into a rampaging devil. All set out on a magical journey which ends both bitter and sweet.The amazing slum background which would have Salvador Dali jumping up and down on a cat in excitement is sheer magical and enchanting to explore. While the puzzles aren't that sophisticated, some can be challenging on the basis that they are slightly vague and will have you scurrying either for a hint box placed in the game which you can don on and run around in or for a youtube walk through. In truth you've probably just missed something obvious like the fact that you can move the buttons as well as press them.Your first run through will be greeted with a metaphor of what happened in the developers personal life, you will also be challenged to go through the entire game a second time, this time without the need of a hint box and the further realization that 25 collectible hats have been hidden in the game.So what are the metaphors in the game? Unlike other games which often be coy about the matter and leave it open the gamer's digression. The developer here wants his story to be told. (Spoiler Alert) The developer (quico) grew up with an abusive father (monster) who was an alcoholic due to the fact that he had accidentally hit someone in his car and killed them. The developer's mother (lulu) always was there for Quico until one day when the monster seemed to have killed lulu (severe abuse) eventually she did get better though through the help of Alejandra (a mixture of the developers first love and his literal little brother) .They at first tried reasoning and hiding the frogs (alcohol) which was making the monster angry. But after one severe abusive bout which took the life of Alejandro Quico eventually realises that he cannot cure this monster and instead has to let this monster go from his life for good. As Quico grows up he drifts away from his dependance of Lulu and pushes the monster away from his life for good after what he witnesses with his attack on Alejandro.The game is well made, because the puzzles aren't that difficult no severe feeling of accomplishment is ever made and so the moral of the story is some what less victorious in feeling. The monster in the game just tosses you about too and is not really that fearing enough to make you sympathise as much as you do in 'Among the Sleep'. The biggest enemy of the game though is it's price. With such a noble meaning and story to a game you would think that they would lower the price so that more could enjoy as the game is also hardly long enough to warrant a large sum. However it should be noted that making games can be a very expensive journey. When asked why he chose frogs to represent bottles of alcohol, the developer replied that it was largely to do with cost. They originally wanted chickens to represent bottles of alcohol in the game, but to put chickens in the game would have cost them $15,000. Since they already had frogs in the game they decided just to go with the frogs and scrap the chickens idea. I have many question marks with that last statement???Anyway the game is seriously worthy of a glance especially if it goes on sale...

content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												If I were to made a list of nice things about this game I would have to mention that graphics are nice, the visual design of the game is fantastic, the soundtrack is amazing and the puzzles are rewarding. But that would leave out the fact that this is an incredibly moving and touching game. It deals with a very serious and personal issue of the game creator's childhood and transforms it into a heartfelt game as a sort of personal therapy. The ending is specially cathartic. A must buy if you want to take a look at what games can do when they go beyond the usual thematic conventions of gaming.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												Perhaps the most emotionally powerful game I've played. Those of you who have read about the game or watched one of the trailers know what the game is about already, but if you haven't, the game is full of metaphors that become clear by the end of the story, and it's devastating.The gameplay itself is wonderful - it's a puzzle platformer, with some neat puzzle mechanics (changing the world to complete your objectives), with one bit right out of "Inception." The puzzles aren't too difficult, and there is even a hint box in every level in case you need a hint. The art direction is terrific (with street art commissioned from actual artists); combined with the music and sound design, it really immerses you in a favela like nothing else.If you are looking for a well-told story that immerses you in the world of a young boy in a Brazilian slum dealing with a monster - I can't recommend this enough.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 27, 2014
												Papo & Yo is a delightful platformer/puzzle game with a very interesting theme. Though the game might at first look seem like a fantasy story of a boy and a monster being friends, it really is about growing up and coming to terms with your childhood. It is a game about how our imagination can help us cope with difficult times, until we are strong enough to take the masks off, see things for what they really are and accept reality for what it is.In essense, Papo & Yo is not an extraordinary game, but it is a very good one. It has a strong and very personal message, one which I believe most people should be able to relate to one way or another. You can't go wrong with it.

content:
Posted: January 7, 2016
												I really wanted to be able to recommend this game, even if only as an experience. It ticks all the boxes I look for in an interesting game - It’s developed in a country not known for their dev studios, it discusses a very real and very important question and it’s technically well executed. But I can’t recommend it as it makes the cardinal error for an interactive experience - it’s plain boring. The theme of parental abuse is overstated and the metaphors crude, but all that could be forgiven if it was only fun to play. As it stands it’s a run-of-the-mill 3d puzzle platformer with unimaginative puzzles with no story telling. Should be played by hardcore explorers of the modern gaming medium due to the reasons in the first paragraph or if you need to write about it. Otherwise stay away.

content:
Posted: March 3, 2014
												First of all, let me just say it got this game through humble bundle about a month or two, but never had the time to play the game until recently. i have not watched any review or let's play of the game, but heard of it through a friend who enjoyed it. other than that, i was completely clueless to what this game could be. also this review is SPOILER FREE.Papo & Yo focuses heavily on story (according to me) and tries to connect it with the surrounding enviroment both in terms of immersion and key elements in gameplay. This sounds great in theory... however the game itself is a mess. The art alone is wonderful and i would definitely recommend Papo Y yo as an art exhibiton rather than as a game. This is because the controls feels very clunky and slow and i personally feel that the lack of "ledgegrabbing" could be... mildly infuriating. Not only that, but the puzzles themselves could be a bit painful due to backtracking without any other mechanic than simply "walking", "climbing" or the painfully slow "getting a box  2 feet away to an adjacent square in the ground".However as i mentioned earlier, Papo & Yo wants to (i think) focus on story and immersion, not the gameplay. When i got the humble bundle, i also got another game that did the same thing and it was called "To the moon". To the moon had half the staff and budget (probably) that Papo & Yo had, but delivered in so many more ways in that. What im trying to say that Papo & Yo doesn't have a story good enough to "carry the game". It feels very rushed, and the immersion just isn't good enough because of it's poorly designed gameplay. There are so many other games (such as "To the moon") which does story much better than Papo & yo, so if your looking for that, i suggest another game.That said, the game has some beautiful art and some great tracks. if you find a deal where you get the game AND the soundtrack, like humble bundle, it could be worth a dime. Buying the game solely on it's own? Not worth it.

number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												To be honest I'm surprised there are so many positive reviews for this game. It is an okay game, and I mean that in the nicest way possible. It is incredibly accessible and heavily story driven so anyone can get through it with relative ease and experience the story. However, that is probably the root of my largest complaint. My main gripe comes with the fact that almost all the "puzzles" in this game are not very clever and feel more like a chore. I never once had an "aha!" moment because it was always incredibly obvious what one needed to do to proceed. This isn't necessarily a negative for all people, but for me it is. For the most part they are just repetitive tasks you must complete to advance to the next zone. Most people rave about the story, and I thought this would be enough to redeem the game for me. Unfortunately, it wasn't. The ending came as no surprise as I thought they were very in your face from the beginning about the identity of the monster. I did however find the meaning of the frogs and their effect on the monster to be used in a way that was well done. Indeed, it wasn't all bad. The game did a good job of easing you into the mechanics and slowly building upon them as the game progressed. I also liked how when the monster became enraged the whole environment shifted and the monster came at you at just the right speed, This was enough to build tension most times I was caught off-guard (not realizing there was a frog around).Lastly I want to say I did enjoy the music and art direction within the game. And a few of the levels (especially towards the end of the game) did some very visually interesting things which made me wish that same creativity could have been used to increase the difficulty of some of the puzzles. In conclusion, I do not recommend this game for the current price of $14.99. However, if you happen to find it dirt cheap (perhaps around or under $5) you might want to give it a go. It is certainly a little adventure, but not one that I would probably take again.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2016
Nice premise, but the slow pace killed it for me.GameplayAll you have to do during the game is jump, push and grab. Not complicated and nicely done. Aiming a jump was at times a bit difficult during the first playthrough. But during the second I was doing well, so I guess it was just a matter of practice. PuzzlesMainly easy but every now and then there was one I had to spend more time on. It may get tedious trying to resolve a puzzle when you are in A and go to B to pick something, return to A only to discover that whatever you picked was useless, go to C, return to A and then go to B to continue to the next puzzle.The puzzles also mark very clearly the different stages in the game, 1 stage // 1 puzzle. For me this was one of the things that impaired the pace of the game.CinematicsDuring the game the cinematics are generally very well executed, meaning you can still control your character while watching them. I feel this is a very pleasant thing to be able to do.However, there are times where a short cinematic would have been welcomed instead of a long sequence of doing nothing but waiting (when going to see the shaman, in the floating isle ). It was pretty frustrating being able to do nothing but turn in circles and playing with the camera.There were times also, where I had the impression that the use of cinematics was unnecessary. There's a puzzle composed of 3 parts near the end of the game (when reviving Lula ) and after each part there is a cinematic telling you that yes! I had beaten that part yay. I know I have done it, I've just did it. Tell me I did well the first time if you want, but not all of them please. CharactersQuicoMain character, nothing much to say about him.LulaQuico's favorite toy. Her (I'm going to assume she's female) first appearance presents her as a guide, she tells Quico how she can help him and how to make use of the new discovered abilities. But that is the only piece of dialogue she gets during the whole game and she becomes more of a tool than a friend.AlejandraGirl that teases Quico into following her and helps him to deal with Monster.MonsterBig lumbering creature that burdens you throughout the game. You must make use of him in order to resolve most of the puzzles.The death of Lula and Alejandra seemed forced, the character were killed because they acted stupidly, Lula could have dodged Monster and Alejandra shouldn't have stood jumping with and enraged Monster behind her. Although I feel those deaths were important, I believe they could have been implemented differently in order to appear more credible. AchievementsHats, why?Although I gather the game has a lot of value I had not a great time playing it, and I'm sorry but a cannot recommend it.

												TL;DR A nice atmospheric game but the simplistic puzzle-work and paper-thin storyline leaves a lot to be desired. Still kinda glitchy on *nix too, nothing gamebreaking though.---Overall if you don't want to think too hard and play a very linear game that'll handhold you through most all puzzles then this game is for you. The enviroments and the music are nice but the gameplay is pretty lacking. Nothing really novel here in story or gameplay best as I can tell. From a performance point of view things run mostly OK on *nix, it does hitch pretty badly at times and the lighting effects can look a bit iffy at times but overall nothing gamebreaking. My biggest nitpick is that despite the large environments there really isn't any incentive to explore from what I can tell. Sure you can look around and see stuff but short of exploring a fairly unpopulated, albeit beautiful, environment for the sake of exploration I don't see much to hold me. From what I've seen this game isn't worth an evening of my time.

content:

												I purchased  this game a few weeks  ago just  because I saw the trailer and the gameplay reminded a lot of Ico for the Ps2, which is one of my fav games of all times. The gameplay of Papo & yo works in a similar way that Ico game, you get into areas, solved a couple of puzzles, turno on switches here and there and that's it. The game is simple, easy to go through and solved the puzzles. Now grafically speaking, the game is just BEAUTIFUL, the environment where the action takes place is just AWESOME, living in South America, in a awesome city with lots of hills and house build on them one above the other kinda feel like the action is taking place in mi city even thoug it's a mix of several architecture cities in South america (Chile, Brazil, Ecuador, Bolivia) which makes it more awesome because it's the first time I saw this kind of environment in a game. I should also  mention  the awesome art/painting in the walls of some buildings, they're incredible, I realized that those painting were actually done by  chilean artists and that some with similar designs are painted  in huge walls around my city, I just love it!!! As for the game quality, it's all thumbs up, music, art/design of the game no complains here and the story is deep, you can notice that the director put a lot of efforts in telling his own personal story and putting it into the game, lot of emotions, I think you should be a grown up to catch the whole plot to understand it though. The music is also excellent, so much that I decided to get the  OST as well.  To sum it up, this game is an excellent story telling/puzzle  kind of game well worth your money. I t won't be a waste I can assure you that.

content:
Posted: October 27, 2014
												A fantastical tale of a boy and a monster set in a surrealistic Brazilian favela.  Papo and Yo is a 3d platformer/adventure game that features some highly unique and quirky puzzles, and though it is a little on the short side, it manges to tell a haunting story nevertheless.   Dealing sensitively with some heavy topics such as alcohol abuse (which the creator suffered through in his childhood) and integrating these issues into a pseudo-fantasy environment, Papo and Yo is a truly one of a kind game that will challenge you both mentally and emotionally.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												Papo & Yo is a lot of things. It's a 3D puzzle game. It's interactive magical realism. It's a meditation on abuse and alcoholism. It's pieced together with a real familiarity with and affection for the assembled look of Brazilian favelas. And it has a autobiographical tone that's nearly impossible to find elsewhere in games.The gameplay is decent. The setting and music are strong. But the real star of the show is Monster. The game couldn't exist without him. For a creature that says nothing and spends half the game sleeping, he's fascinatingly complex. You'll switch between trying to protect him and trying to escape from him at a moment's notice. You're trying to break his addiction, but sometimes you'll use that addiction to force him to do what you want. You'll find yourself clinging to the brief moments he shows some affection, even if it's nothing more than a half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥toss of football. You want to like Monster, though you'll repeatedly ask yourself if you should even bother. It's a juggling act, but you'll find yourself practicing quite a bit of cognitive dissonance as you go from puzzle to puzzle.The game isn't subtle in its metaphors, nor should it be. Think of it as a children's story about abuse. It's like Where the Wild Things Are, except instead of wild creatures as stand-ins for the anarchy of childhood, Monster stands for a child's perspective of the physical power, aloofness, and cruelty of adulthood.

content:
Posted: July 28, 2014
												I'll say 8/10. If you are interested in this sort of game, you should play it. It is good, but it is not a great 9 or 10 game. It is a puzzle game, figuring out how to get from here to there, moving platforms, jumping, etc. The puzzles were varied and unique, and I was sometimes challenged, but never frustrated.The plot is that you are a boy, running through a magical version of Brazil (maybe, I wasn't sure). You spend most of the game in a poorer section of the city, but you can pull levers to make buildings move. You have a beloved robot companion, a monster that follows you around, and a mysterious girl. But all of this is a dream, because in the real world your father is an abusive alcoholic. Monster, is of course, your father. Normally, Monster is Ok. You can use him to jump to higher ledges, or activate switches. He walks arounds, and sleeps a lot. But when Monster eats a frog he becomes a flaming demon of pain.This game did a great job of controlling my emotions. In the beginning, Monster isn't so bad. Maybe even helpful. But as the game progressed, I found myself hating Monster. Really hating him. And hating frogs. I would smash every frog I saw, and I have never wanted to murder (no defeat, not slay -- murder) a monster more.

content:
Posted: January 23, 2014
												Wow, what to say about this game!  When I bought this game, I did not know what to expect.  To be very honest, I did not even know what the game was about, other than it was an action/platformer game.  The story of this game is rather deep for such a childrens style game.I don't really want to post any spoilers, but you run around as a kid named Quico whose father is an alcoholic.  You are in what seems to be a dream world where you have to solve puzzles and platform your way across each area to progress the story.  The puzzles are not overly hard, but the game is just fun and the story is a big metaphor.The game is relatively short, but I believe you can play through twice just for the achievements.  Overall, this was one of the most enjoyable games I have played in the last year.  I did not want to stop playing! Part of me wishes it were longer, but another part is glad it was the length it was, because it did feel just right.Anyhow, if you are looking for a action/platform/puzzle game that has a pretty good metaphoric driven story and is fun to boot, well I think this is right up your alley!

content:
Posted: January 21, 2014
												Papo & Yo is a delightful platformer/puzzle game with a very interesting theme. Though the game might at first look seem like a fantasy story of a boy and a monster he befriends, it really is about growing up and coming to terms with your childhood. It is a game about how our imagination can help us cope with difficult times, until we are strong enough to take the masks off, see things for what they really are and accept reality for what it is.The game itself isn't very challenging, but the platformer controls can be a bit finnicky from time to time. The environments of the game are well made and it is fun to see how the world shifts as you solve the puzzles. The game is fairly short but it definitely keeps you invested in it until its very appropriate and memorable ending.In essense, Papo & Yo is not an extraordinary game, but it is a very good one. It has a strong and very personal message, one which I believe most people should be able to relate to one way or another. You can't go wrong with it.

content:
Posted: January 24, 2014
												I was gripped the moment the game loaded. From the artistic main menu, to the absolutely gorgeous look to the game, to the fluid game play and stellar control feel, this game is top notch. In fact it makes some of the other titles that I've been playing lately  all of a sudden feel mundane.I've noticed a few reviewers have felt the game to be boring, but this wasn't the case for me at all. It was SUCH a refreshing change from the usual "gun and ammo seeking" games that have flooded the market. Trying to kill everything that moves before it kills you is not part of this game at all...you're actually trying to help someone who needs help. I suspect that those who didn't like this game fall into the COD or war gamer category, and that's not me.If you're remotely curious about this game then dive in and get it! You won't be disappointed. 9/10

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 25, 2014
												Papo y Yo is a 3rd person action platformer. Its basic controls and easy to understand mechanics allows its charm to shine through. The story is centered around Quico, a south american boy, that sets out to find why he is cursed. He follows a mysterious girl around in search of the answer to his quest. He comes to find that his curse is to be paired with a monster who is usually disinterested in him but will turn in a moments notice and attack Quico when presented with some mysterious tree frogs. Quico has the ability, or the task, rather of manipulating his world. The south american favela setting is both oppressive and beautiful; at times the world is vivid and imaginative. Traversing the various puzzles can drastically change them in ways you would never expect. As the story unfolds you come to find that the metaphors run deep and will certainly hit hard. The only complaint I have with Papo y Yo is that while the story is superb, it ends too soon. I suppose for the underlying subject matters, no spoilers, its best for this to be a short experience. The game is beautiful, and easy to pick up and play. It's a 4 to 6 hour romp that is worth its asking price. Go check it out.
