Posted: May 4, 2013
												My god. This game dredged up memories of a time when I had to let go of a best friend of mine because of illegal drug use. It was alcohol specifically, that made me decide. In the moment when he broke into a liquor cabinet and began to get drunk, (while of course being underage.), I was afraid. I let him get drunker and drunker, and when he was stumbling around and falling down, I got in my car, (which had his stuff and the stuff of the people who were with us.) , and I left and drove to his parents house. I deposited everyone's stuff on the front porch and rang the doorbell and told his dad where he was and what he was doing. Afterwords, I never looked back. I haven't seen him in years now, nor do I want to, but I just know, if I saw him again I could become friends again with him easily. But I took the harder route of not forgiving him and simply letting him go. The ending of Papo and Yo was a metaphor for an actual moment in my life, and it was one of , if not THE most, moving ending to a video game I have ever seen. Millage may vary for other people, but at least for me, I felt very moved. It was just like revisiting that moment again, but this time, I was able to let go more easily. This is a game that simply must be played. It is a beautiful piece of art.

Posted: September 30, 2014
												Buy? Maybe.Long story short, Papo & Yo is another one of those obtuse and vague story telling indie games that will appear pretentious and confusing to many gamers or groundbreaking and wonderful for others. While I largely enjoyed the games easy, but not handholding puzzles and "Mystical chalk" in a Central/South American favela art style, I ended up mostly confused and not very satisfied with the ending. The ending was abrupt, and like the entirty of the storystelling, all based on metaphors. Papo & Yo is a game built more for the types that enjoyed Dear Esther (ugh) and Thomas Was Alone (A pretty nice game actually) and a bit less for those that enjoyed Portal 2 or Majin and the Forsaken Kingdom - the puzzles are nice, but hardly brain-teasing or super innovative. I will say that seeing how the world forms and deforms through puzzles solving is really interesting and neat, but like any pretentious indie game, it is never explained how or why parts of buildings can suddenly sprout legs to walk or wings to fly, or why entire towns can be split and connected like a jigsaw puzzle: You're just supposed to "understand" some nebulous meaning and interpret what is going on, like guessing "This is the kid's imagination or how he understand the world works because he is just a kid" or something like that. While it is also clear that this is supposed to be a story about a child and an unclear relationship to his father manifested in a frog eating monster representing an alcohol abusing father, the exposition is all metaphorical and based on the developer's artistic vision, It's less understandable like a good Pixar short or the "Kiwi!" film where you understand the actions and emotions.If you need further proof of what I'm talking about, see the discussion thread about "What does it all mean?!" between players and developers, where the dev doesn't answer the question and instead thanks the players for debating what is going on: http://steamcommunity.com/app/227080/discussions/0/828936718797549690/Papo & Yo gets on my good side for being a short, easy to finish game with a good art style, world design and an overall solid game (fits my Ultra-wide monitor resolution and I had no glitches besides a few graphical glitches early in the game). It gets on my bad side for being another "Guess at what story I'm trying to tell you instead of me actually telling you" arty/farty indie game. The story may strike a cord with other gamers who have experiened child abuse from their parents. This is something playable for children as well, but I doubt they would understand all the real world paralells the game is trying to make, Papo & Yo is essentially an adults game.

Posted: September 2, 2013
												A barely disguised allegory, the game is occasionally overbearing in its message.  The puzzling and platforming is usually just this side of tedious.  Nevertheless I love this game as it's a perfect example of the interactive form being the correct choice for telling a particular story.  Fear, frustration, and the magical beliefs of a child thinking he can change what is through the few options available to him make for a near seamless intertwining of feeling, meaning, and gameplay.  There were times when I refused to do what the game asked of me; other times it gave me chills as I tried to process how I felt about what was happening.  The art and music are glorious.  Well worth the 3 hours it will take to play to completion.

Posted: January 19, 2014
												I wasn't expecting much from Papo & Yo but ws very pleasantly surprised.Papo & Yo tells a very sad (and very real) story through a compelling narrative and clever gameplay. While it may seem to be a game for children, it's mature subject matter means some parental guidance would be advisable before letting them play.While the story may not be for kids, the visuals, audio and gameplay certainly are. The environments are more less variations of the same favela theme but some certainly do stick out as particularly pretty. The audio is great and befits the environment. The soundtrack especially is outstanding; a beautiful selection of Latin American instrumentals.The gameplay is a mixed bag. The puzzles while simple are fun to solve thanks to some unique mechanics and smart level design. The only gripe I have is with the lack of an auto follow camera forcing the player to control the camera manually all the time. The game is short but fulfilling nonetheless.Papo & Yo is a fantastic little game masking a touching story of some real world issues. It is well worth a play through, if only to experience the story, mechanics and level design.

Posted: April 14, 2015
												There's not too much I can say about this game without spoiling the plot and diminishing its emotional impact, but here's what I will say.This game is relatively simple, as far as mechanics go. It's a basic puzzle/platformer; it isn't too difficult skill-wise, nor will you likely get stumped by any of the puzzle elements. Mechanically it's actually a very easy game - even taking my time and messing up a bit here and there, I still finished it in less than 4 hours. Despite that, it was one of the most difficult games for me to complete on an emotional level.I really relate to the main character, Quico. What this game lacks in mechanical complexity it completely makes up for in emotional intensity and engagement. It will hit you right in the feels, over and over. It's not hard to tell that this was a very personal subject for the game's main creator, and I think he and the creative team tackled it very well. They have my utmost gratitude for making this game. Honestly, if anyone ever asks me about my relationship with my stepfather, rather than explain it to them with words I could just have them play this game. It definitely goes onto my favorites list, and although I can't say it's one I'll play again anytime soon, I'm very much grateful for the experience it brought me.

Posted: December 29, 2013
												This is a very personal game about a boy trying to befriend his abusive parent. It has an unexpected and emotionally powerful ending, just like Brothers. Papo & Yo also excels in gameplay - lots of exploration, platforming and puzzles in a surreal ghetto, where the chalkboard drawings of children magically come to life. Also, it's an indie game that tries and almost succeeds at having a triple A quality and polish. One of the best games that came out this year.

Posted: December 20, 2013
												Truly a fantastic adventure game! Papo & Yo will not only present you with interesting puzzles and fun gameplay, but also challenge you to look inward to the demons we all battle throughout life (and more importantly the places we go to escape them).This is a game about a boy named Quico and his seemingly magical action figure Lula, as well as a giant - and normally docile - beast named Monster. As Quico, you will explore various facets of the dream-like favela he escapes to, where the laws of reality itself bend to the whim of one little boy.The core gameplay focuses on solving environmental puzzles, many of which involve magic chalk-like drawings on the walls and floors of buildings that let you manipulate this strange and beautiful world in a variety of different ways. There is also some light platforming and some interesting mechanics which involve Lula, who straddles your backside like a knapsack and acts as a sort of jetpack that can also carry out some basic commands (such as flipping switches for you at a distance). Monster will also play a big part (no pun intended) in solving a lot of said puzzles and offers his own unique mechanics; when he is asleep his massive gut can be used as a trampoline of sorts and of course that brute strength of his also comes in handy! You have to be careful, however, as Monster also has an unhealthy addiction to poisonous frogs which cause him to burst into flames and go on a rampage!All in all this is a refreshing take on 3D puzzle-platformers, that also reminds us just how beautiful and robust the Unreal Engine can still be when in the right hands.

Posted: August 27, 2014
												Just wow. Concise and poignant, this game is filled with sublime vistas of childhood wonder brought to life. The gameplay itself is elegant, and the mechanics reinforce the narrative of the game. I cannot say enough to convey how amazingly well executed the theme and story of the game is, from the devolving normalcy of the scenarios you encounter, to the sparse but powerful cutscenes that hit you like trainwreck. By the time I was done, I had become a bundle of emotions, both profoundly sad yet simultaneously uplifted by the ordeal I had participated in. The game reads as a catharsis on the part of it lead designer, Vander Callabero, and I wonder if its narrative could be, in part, healing for those who have gone through similar crises. I'd challenge anyone who doesn't believe that video games can be art to play this game and still support that opinion.Stop reading this and just go and experience this story.

Posted: November 29, 2014
												This game is, in a word, stunning.Since I opened Papo & Yo, I've been admittedly obsessed. The way that the developers (Minority) managed to tie in mature and serious themes like alcoholism and domestic violence without using gratuitous violence or gore is commendable. In fact, Papo & Yo doesn't contain any gore at all! The story is truly captivating and you find yourself getting increasingly attached to the characters as time goes on, despite the minimal use of dialogue.The gameplay itself is mainly a mix of casual puzzles and platforming. It's a simplistic way of bolstering the narrative, and was implemented amazingly. There are only a few achievements, but I had a lot of fun getting them all. A second playthrough of the game allows for collecting hats (which appear on dolls seen throughout the game).I'm not one for writing serious reviews, but this game is deserving of nothing short of a proper review. Completing this game felt like a spiritual experience, and I'll be sure to do it again soon. Whatever the price is for this game right now, it's worth every penny.

It's a very refreshing game, making a point while giving you some really cool puzzles. it tries to engage you in the 'story' and, for me, did this quite nicely with subtle metaphors and imagery. Different people will experience this game differently, if you want a game that is just about the action or puzzles, this might disappoint, but I found it to be an incredibly chilled out game, you can't die and the music is very well done, fitting the atmosphere without becoming repetative. The graphics on the trailer look really poor, but I was surprised by how nice it looked.When I finished the game I felt like it could have been longer with more puzzles, but at the same time, I played it through in one night and it was a cool little game that kept me entertained start to finish. In some ways, the fact that it's short makes it more enjoyable.If you can get it on sale then I recommend it, it's very different and if you can think of it loosely like paying for a film, in this case a puzzle 'experience', then it's well worth £8.

Posted: January 12, 2014
												Surprisingly amazing game, very nice and laid back with interesting although fairly simple puzzles. The game takes on the main protagonist of Papo and delves into the true meaning of what the game is about. Its interesting as not many games are able to take on adult content such as this one and provide real impact especially one on an emotional level without just showing something in full blatant force. It feels like the game takes on adult themes in a very  subtle way which makes it more interesting as you play different parts of the game and wonder what each part truly means. The game is fairly short where I finished it in one day which feels really good as its not long enough to drag on and also shows the main focus which is a lot of story, puzzles and plat forming. For an indie game I didn't expect too much and so was pleasantly surprised to find out how great the game is. As a puzzle game its also quite interesting although can be quite simple at times. The best part of the simplicity of the puzzle is that it feels like you're always moving forward kind of like if you start a good run and you don't really want to stop. This creates a good flow to the game as I never felt that I had to just stop and think, or get annoyed and trying random things until something happened. I would definitely give it a recommendation, especially if you're looking for a fairly short and intriguing indie game.

Posted: January 15, 2015
												Not to add more praise onto an already well liked game, but Papo & Yo is as great as everyone says.  I'll keep my review short and to the point.First off, its a short game, but it hits all the right points for the right amount.  It's like having a well portioned meal that satisfies and doesn't leave you sick afterwards.The twist is pretty much given away in both the trailers and the beginning of the game itself, however I wouldn't say that it takes away from any of the impact of the game. Just about everything mechanically about the game is just as I said before, cut down to the right size.  There aren't a ton of characters, but the ones we get are very expressive and nice to look at.  Take a look at all the animation in Monster's face when you hop on his belly.  The backgrounds have a surreal-realism to them with the stacked buildings mixed with the sugar cube mystic blocks.  Nice music and sound too that share that south american feel.The puzzles never got too hard, just a lot of surevying the area for clues (plus each area has a clever tutorial hint).  No need to console the internet for answers.  Puzzles that involve are raging Monster can be tricky as he can stall you by tossing you around a bit if you are caught.As someone who didn't have addict parents I could only relate on a passive level, however by the end I think I have a better understanding of what it is like.  All-in-all, I would recommend this game because it combines great gameplay with a tragic story.  This could have easily been a heavy handed tale or a good message with awful gameplay, but Minority managed create a gem.

Posted: July 9, 2014
												I got this game a long time ago with an Humble Bundle, and finally got around to play it.I'm really really glad that I did. I loved this game, its astounding ambientation, its nice puzzle nature.Let's try to be objective and methodic:-Story: 7/10 The story isn't that great, but it's a break from classic puzzles, it's entertaining enough, and the end packs a punch.-Longevity/Replay value: 4/10 This is the worst part: it takes 3/4 hours to finish it, and once you finish it for the first time, there is really nothing compellingyou to play it again.-Difficulty: 6/10 Pretty much all the puzzles are very straightforward and easy to solve, with the hint box it's even easier. Both on the mental side and the skill required to put it in practice. Failing has no real consequences, as you never really "die" and the worst case scenario is losing a few seconds to respawn, but in the game everything stays as it was, so you don't even have to restart the level. This can be a pro (no frustration) or a con (shorter longevity).-Aesthetic: 10/10 This is the strongest point of the game. The ambientation, some kind of favelas, and the effect that solving the puzzle has on it is simply amazing. It has something mystical mixed with some kind of visual poetry. I greatly enjoyed it. Also kudos to the creators for the cure put into every little detail. Just lovely.-Concept: 9/10 Puzzles that change the conformation of the ambient surrounding you are not really so new, but not that common either.Plus, the implementation is brilliant.-Controls: 7/10 Pretty straightforward. Usual wasd + mouse, third person. The cam is usually fine, in some rare occasion can move awkwardly. But those occasions are very rare, and failing has no big consequences (see "Difficulty")-OST: 8/10 The soundtrack is not, strictly speaking, memorable. But it always fit the game, is easy to the ears, nice, and really helps feeling part of the game.AVG: 7.3It's worth the 11€? I'm not sure. But I'm also pretty stingy.What I can say for sure is that it's worth adding to the wishlist and get on a sale.

Posted: April 28, 2014
												Today I played through Papo & Yo (Minority Media Inc.﻿), an action adventure (mostly 3D puzzle platforming) about a young boy who escapes the abuse of his alcoholic father into a surrealistic Latin American–esque slum, where he embarks on a quest to cure "Monster" of its addiction to poisonous frogs. The monster (a very clearly indicated metaphor for the protagonist's father) is both a helpful aid it surmounting obstacles and progressing through the game's environment, but also the game's only true "enemy" (when under the influence of frogs), who becomes not only a danger to others, but also the protagonist himself, who in the end discovers that there is no cure for "Monster". So, it's basically a journey of acceptance and letting go.An enjoyable game—not very difficult, but the environments and puzzles were interesting and non–repetitive. There were occasional glitches and I had to replay one section when Monster got stuck on the environment and blocked progress, but nothing game–breaking. Notable is that the character you play as is non–White and non–Western (although there is no explicit nationality or ethnicity), and also non–English speaking (but not Spanish or Portuguese, either—some sort of constructed or conglomerate language is used in the game's limited dialog). Sad that playing as something other then a White male American is "notable", but that's how it is…

Posted: August 2, 2013
												The graphics aren't groundbreaking (although they are beautiful) and there are some collision issues and places I got my character (physically) stuck. That being said, the story this game tells is heart wrenching! You start off chasing a mysterious girl who can seemingly create doors and portals out of thin air. To chase her, you complete some easy puzzles with your robot friend (who hangs on your back and assists you in opening areas that you can't reach). Shortly after, you meet a large pink monster who helps you out in completing some more puzzles. That's when you start getting glimpses of places and things (in what seems like another universe), and you realise that everything you do just might be a metaphor for something that has happened to you. You can manipulate the world and it's objects by moving gears and cranks that are shining with an other-worldly glow. A few times my mind went "whaaaa?", but I still had lots of fun. The music was beautifully composed, and near the very end, it was bringing out so many emotions as the music (and story) unraveled. Even though it was only about 3-3.5 hours to play through, I think it was the perfect length to tell the story it needed to tell.

Posted: December 2, 2013
												Gameplay: 9/10Storyline: 9/10Graphics: 8/10SoundTrack: 9/10Overall: 8.75/10The game puts players in the shoes of Quico, a boy whose complex fantasies are loosely tied with the real world.  Think the dilapidated, South American version of the Hundred Acre Woods.  Quico is looking for a way to cure his monster friend, as every time he eats poison frogs(alcohol), he goes on a rampage, destroying all in his path.  Otherwise, the monster is a peaceful being, and even saves your skin if you mess up in certain puzzles.  At its core, Papo & Yo has a metaphorical, psuedo-autobiographical story that was inspired by the childhood experiences of Minority’s creative director, Vander Caballero.

Posted: December 6, 2013
												On first sight, Papo & Yo could be made for a younger audience. And if you'd leave the story-elements aside, Papo & Yo would be just that. The Gameplay is simple, the mechanics are easy and it is no challenge to beat the game. But Papo & Yo doesn't try to be challenging, it tries to tell a story. The story of a boy who escapes into his own imagination to seek shelter from his alcoholic father, the "monster" if you will. And in his imagination, still, he tries to "heal" the monster from its addiction to frogs.Papo & Yo tells this story in a metaphorical but so profound way, sometimes you just need to turn off the game and think about what just happened. As a game Papo & Yo is nothing special, but as a tool to express a story it is unique. 8.5/10PS: The Soundtrack is superb. I bought this game without the Soundtrack and after playing trough Papo & Yo I feel pretty bad about it.

Posted: December 5, 2013
												This game is a masterpiece! It's the only game I've ever played that left tears in my eyes. Highly personal, and very fun, Papo and Yo is a game about a boy trying to cope with his abusive father. This game opens wounds, but not in a bad way. Instead of determining to make a statement, and pointing it out to you, Papo and Yo immerses you into the story, letting you dictate how you feel about the situations presented. The gameplay is puzzle based. It's inventive and very imaginative, but not difficult. Do not expect to burnout your brain trying to solve the puzzles. This game is more about the storyline and your personal reaction to it. Your first play through will probably be 2 - 3 hours; so it's not a bad game to play on a lazy afternoon. The graphics are done well with a rich color palette and tones to make you feel you are in the slums. The voice acting is spot on. I know I'm lavishing over this game, but I really can't say enough good things about it. If there was ever a game I wished everyone would play at least once, it would be Papo and Yo!

No fighting.Just a really sad story.Very pretty looking and the music matched.It reminded me of something thatgamecompany would develop. (They are a SONY company that made JOURNEY and FLOWER. Both very unique games.)If you're into artistic games, this is for you.

Posted: December 4, 2013
												First, I'll say that I enjoy games with immersive atmosphere, story, and a unique artistic vision.  Papo & Yo manages to get all three of those to work together to create a truly unique experience.Above all else, I would call Papo & Yo a 3D adventure game, and the puzzles are worked into the environment in a way that makes them engaging though not the most innovative in the genre.  That's ok, however, because the real star of this game is the immersive experience of wandering through this fantastical favela, appreciating the colorful artwork, and dissecting the meaning and symbolism behind it all.I don't know if my interpretation behind some of the imagery was intended by the developers, but when a video game can rise to the level of having multiple interpretations, you know it's something special!  The shift from colorful and sunny to drab and rainy...  The graffiti so intentionally placed in each scene...  The act of moving great buildings and how it relates to both boyhood imagination as well as the main character's role in his troubled father's life...I experienced no bugs.  The visuals are stunning when using the highest graphical settings.  Look around, pause and enjoy the music, and take it in slowly to make the experience last.The little gems of creativity, the perfect soundtrack, a story unheard of in the game industry, and the sense of wonder you feel as you explore this world simply cannot be missed by any gamer who believes that games can be art.

Posted: December 26, 2013
												Ico-esque adventure game where your companion is [very explicitly] a big, hulking metaphor for the game creator's abusive, alcoholic father. Subtle this game was not ... but it *was* unique, and in the end it did have a real effect on me. I'm very glad to have played it, but it's heavy enough that I'm unlikely to play through it again.Strengths: Really striking and original visuals / artistic direction, superb music, refreshing protagonist [the opposite of the powerfulwhitemale we so often see in games]. Short length, ~3.5 hours [a big plus given my schedule].Weaknesses: The gameplay itself is a bit repetitive [though the constant introduction of new visuals and mechanics does liven things up]. The puzzles are trivial [this is an adventure game, not a puzzle game]. Some minor control+camera wonkiness. Complete lack of subtlety in hitting you with the game's central metaphor [this game's creator is making a very personal, cathartic game.]

Posted: July 8, 2014
												Alcohol abuse can be a sensitive and personal topic and in this game it’s presented in a blatant, realistic and yet tasteful manner. This is due to the game being well designed, possibly due to the creative director’s own experience with an alcoholic father.You never quite know whether Monster is your friend of your enemy. You have this constant sense of unease around him that he might find a poisonous frog and turn on you. But Monster is incredibly useful when he’s not charging you down. I also have to hand it to the composer, Brian D’Oliveira, for creating a light, flamenco soundtrack that ties in well with lightness of Quico’s steps and scenery. The story is well-presented and well-plotted, both visually, aurally and through the gameplay.This praise all being said, the game isn’t without its flaws. Like many platformers, the game has an element of exploration which the designers failed to… explore. There’s plenty of nooks, crannies and hidey holes, but nothing in them. I even managed to find trapped teddy bears in many of them, but they seemed to be nothing more than coincidently-placed scenery. I felt that this beautiful and unique world was just a bit too empty, nothing to encourage me to play again and no reward for getting to these hard to reach places, not quite what I expect from a platformerFor full review, visit:http://icarusreviews.net/2014/04/21/papo-yo/

Posted: July 29, 2014
												I have mixed feelings about Papo & Yo.On the other hand I want to love the game for it's unique feel, but on the other I feel it is lacking on many fronts.At it's best Papo & Yo offers beautiful artwork and sceneries, entertainment and a fun challenge. At it's worst, it is very repetitive, frustrating and even boring. It also hosts a selection of glitches, that aren't that big of a deal, but do leave an unpolished impression.The story had me intrigued at first, but lost me after a while because of it's slow progress. Also, it's really not well carried out tbh. I did however finish the game for I wanted to get to the predictable end. Seeing the credits scroll down on the screen didn't offer the satisfaction I thought it would, other than finally getting the game off my to-do list. It was a bit like finishing a mediocre book.Still, I won't advice to steer clear of the game. If you have the patience and are willing to forgive some annoyances (many that are due to budget) Papo & Yo delivers a different kind of gameplay experience that other game makers should learn from and improve on. It is good to see that more and more people like Vander Caballero (the creative director, who the story is based on) take the effort to get off their high horses at big game studios to go and discover their own path.

Posted: September 2, 2013
												A barely disguised allegory, the game is occasionally overbearing in its message.  The puzzling and platforming is usually just this side of tedious.  Nevertheless I love this game as it's a perfect example of the interactive form being the correct choice for telling a particular story.  Fear, frustration, and the magical beliefs of a child thinking he can change what is through the few options available to him make for a near seamless intertwining of feeling, meaning, and gameplay.  There were times when I refused to do what the game asked of me; other times it gave me chills as I tried to process how I felt about what was happening.  The art and music are glorious.  Well worth the 3 hours it will take to play to completion.

Posted: June 27, 2014
												This game was the gone home before gone home. This games tells the the player a tragic story by having you play as a the son or victim of this tragedy. As you progess through the narrative... it becomes clear that this story is less about the art style and gameplay but more about telling the story of dealing with tragedy... that we don't often see in games nowadays. Don't exoect instant gratification or a great payoff. Invest your time in the story and you will come away feeling a lot better for having played this game. I remember pre-ordering this game and I normally do not pre-order a game of this type... but something compelled me to do so. I still can't find what truly compelled me because it is hard to put into words how satisfied I am for having played this game. There are very few games that I can hold the narrative and objective of the game in such high regard. This is one of them.

Posted: January 11, 2014
												It will make you feel.  This interactive media makes you look at pain and love.  Specifically the pain caused by an evil drunken father and the confusing love felt by a son.  You feel along with the son.  The son loves his sister and she is also in pain.  The confusion of having a father,  who's rage must be managed and avoided and who will has fun playing and laughing with you, is a discovery.  It is emotional to the point that I felt like avoiding it and then it was so fascinatingly truthful in its depth that I could not disengage.  I know more than I did before I experienced this.  I think that was the goal of the man who made it and I know he was sucessful in teaching and sharing somthing from his life.  I was sad and angry durring this experience.  I guess that is the key feature of this game.   It has fastinating visuals and surreal, reality bending puzzles but at its core this is about sharing feelings.  Thank you Papo & Yo.

												I managed to beat it in around 3-4 hours.But it was a well-enjoyed 3-4 hours. Like a lot of indie games, it's meant to be experienced more than anything. But it's not really something that tries too hard to be overly deep and the symbolism is made pretty clear by the end. In fact, the second trailer pretty much spells it out for you before you play. The game draws inspiration from the creator's real life experiences with an alcoholic father. It's good, but you may want to take a pass if themes like alcholism and abuse are overwhelming to you.I'd rather not give away the ending, so I'll just say that if you want to see it, you'll have to play for yourself. I personally think it would be worth the $15, although I got it on sale. But since not everyone might agree with me, I'd say just get it on the next sale if you're not 100% sure. You might not feel like you're getting much out of it as a game. It's short and pretty simple. But as an experience, I'd recommend it.

												A very beautiful game. I played this back to back with Portal 2 and at first I was a little disappointed with Papo & Yo's puzzles by comparison. As the game went on though I came to appreciate that Papo & Yo has different goals than Portal and as a result different puzzles. Papo & Yo, to me at least, is a metaphor for navigating family dynamics. Its goal is to put you in a child's shoes, to oscillate between the calm and terror of having an alcoholic father, not to offer arbitrary brain teasers.

Posted: February 9, 2016
												Anyone who's ever shared a home with an abusive person knows that the management of the aggressor's precarious mental state is key to everyday survival. You're always walking on eggshells, never trusting periods of respite, for you know all too well how little it takes to tip the balance. It's a dangerous tango that, in a morbid way, lends itself rather well to gamification. "Monster", the lumbering, troll-like form the violent father assumes in the child's imagination, must be carefully guided and appeased in order to navigate the game world. It'll have you fooled with its ungainly cuteness, only to erupt into (literally) flaming rage the instant it tastes blood. Make no mistake, this is no game for children. The presentation may be beautiful and the core platforming joyous, but the final act in particular takes a turn for the guttingly sinister. Definite recommendation, but be prepared to be challenged emotionally.

Posted: September 9, 2015
												Not perfect but a game that should be played. Papo & Yo is about a boy with an abusive father who escapes into a fantasy world where he needs the help of a brutish monster named Papo to help you slove platforming puzzles.This game is very pretty.  bright, colorful, and atmospheric.  The tone and art style gradually changes as the story progresses and grows darker.  Most of the game involves using Papo to help you get around by lifting obsticals or tossing you to high ledges and then you need to manipulate the enviroment so Papo can follow.  There are also slugs that Papo really loves but cause him to go into a rage and attack anything near him including you.  Sometimes you need to keep him away from the slugs sometimes you need to let him eat them so you can solve a puzzle.  It's hear were your relationship with the monster begins to mirror your relationship with your abusive father.  The game does have some flaws.  its not the longest game, sometimes the physics are a little wonky and there could be a bit more variety in the game play but its not enough to be a deal brekerThis is a fairly simple puzzle platformer with appealing visuals and does a good job of letting the narrative and charm bleed into the gameplay.  It also explores a topic not offten tackled in video games.

Posted: January 3, 2015
												Can games help us process psychological traumas? Or help us understand them in others? This unconventional game tries exactly that.In Papo & Yo you play a little boy named Quico that finds his way through a dreamlike Favela, following a mysterious girl. The environment offers creative puzzles that emphasizes whats possible in the fantasy of a kid. But this fantasy is not only that, it is also a metaphor. After befriending a monster that loves to eat frogs but starts raging everytime it does you realize that not all is well in Quicos fantasy world, and even less so in his real world.Without hitting you in the face with it Papo & Yo not only tells you, but lets you experience how traumatising domestic violence can be for a child and how it tries to cope with it. It handles the subject very delicately and at the same time offers great and challenging gameplay.The shortness of it is not a weak point as it gets the point across with good pacing. It also features good art and music - Another example of how interactive media can offer mature experiences without clichés or over the top violence.

Posted: July 27, 2013
												It's a surprisingly affecting story. The monster, Papo, is a metaphor for the alcoholic father of the game's director. But what could have easily been a preachy mess turns out to be an engaging puzzle game with a poignant story. The Brazilian favela makes for an interesting setting, the music is lovely, and the ending actually chocked me up. The only downside is that it's quite short, only about 3-4 hours, but I ended up playing it a second time just because I enjoyed the world and characters so much. Highly recommended.[UPDATE] I just nominated Papo & Yo for the “I'm Not Crying, There's Something In My Eye” Award in this year's Steam Awards. It was a tough choice between this, Gone Home, and Valiant Hearts; but there is something special about Papo & Yo. It touches on a subject that has affected me personally, so it ultimately got my vote. I hope you'll consider it, too.

Posted: July 7, 2015
												I'd like to put an asterisk on my recommendation. It is a good game, in my opinion worth buying and playing, and I enjoyed every moment of it.However, here's the caveat: it's not a challenging game. It's very much Railroading: the game, with a few obstacles to get you more invested in it (still better than "Dear Esther"). To me, that's not a problem, because the game's atmosphere, music and visuals are excellently designed, and the brazilian voices (I'm assuming it's brazilian) are a delight to listen to. For some however, this might be a problem. If you need a proper challenge to enjoy a game, this is definitely not for you. As mentioned, the puzzles are simple; just find the next switch to open the path to the next setpiece. A few puzzles require a bit of fiddling to solve, in particular a basketball court that took me a few reloads to get back on track, but it didn't make me use my head as a scratching post.It's a short game; as you can see from my play counter, it was completed in less than 4 hours. It's short, but sweet, and I'd argue that's its selling point; it doesn't drag out the overarching theme about substance abuse ad infinitum, and while the ending didn't grab me, that's not a fault of the game. It's nice to see such work put into telling the message of substance abuse seen through the eyes of a young boy, as it is quite a serious problem in the world today, and the game is just beautiful, as I've already said. Buy it for the experience, not for the challenge.

Posted: November 9, 2014
												I don't like platformer.  I don't like jumping puzzles.  I especially don't like timing puzzles.  I'm not very good at any of those.  Because of that, I should not have liked this game.  But I did.  I liked this game a lot.The gameplay was simple enough that I could play through it without getting seriously frustrated by my lack of skill; but still challenging enough not to be boring.   The puzzles that did not involve jumping and timing were very clever, but for the most part still logical and intuitive once you got into the flow of the game.  There were a few odd moments where the puzzles did not make a whole lot of sense, and I was force to rely on a walkthrough; but very few (unlike so many modern puzzle games, where randomness is used as a cheap and easy substitute for cleverness).  The mechanics of the game are very entertaining in themselves, particularly once Lulu is introduced.The game design is beautiful; and the creators use of an uncommon setting was brilliant.  The third-world backdrop meshed very well with the fantastical elements; creating a seamless world with it's own unique and readily-identifiable logic.  The artwork is stunning, and the inclusion of works by actual environmental artists nothing short of amazing.  The similar use of third-world characters, rather than white Europeans or stereotypical fantasy creatures is similarly inspiring.  The music is beautiful, and in spots almost breathtaking, wonderfully blending traditional and orchestral sounds.  Atmospheric and fun at the same time.I would be hard pressed to find any flaws in the game.  If I did, I would say that parts of the ending felt a little out of place.  Some of the scenes and actions didn't make quite as much sense as they could have, and the symbolism is a bit heavyhanded; but that's still a fairly minor quibble.   The game is a bit shorter than most of its type; but too much longer and it would have started to drag.  The pacing never leave it feeling too long or too short.One warning is that the background story that emerges from the game is disturbing, becoming increasingly so the closer it gets to the end.  This is ultimately a story of addiction and child abuse; and is accordingly dark and sad.  Fortunately, the writers do not beat the player over the head with moralizing; and manage to balance the darkness with a keen sense of human resilience.  I cannot recommend this game enough.  I picked it up at a huge discount during one of Steam's big sales; but would can easily recommend getting it even at full price.

Posted: September 30, 2014
												Buy? Maybe.Long story short, Papo & Yo is another one of those obtuse and vague story telling indie games that will appear pretentious and confusing to many gamers or groundbreaking and wonderful for others. While I largely enjoyed the games easy, but not handholding puzzles and "Mystical chalk" in a Central/South American favela art style, I ended up mostly confused and not very satisfied with the ending. The ending was abrupt, and like the entirty of the storystelling, all based on metaphors. Papo & Yo is a game built more for the types that enjoyed Dear Esther (ugh) and Thomas Was Alone (A pretty nice game actually) and a bit less for those that enjoyed Portal 2 or Majin and the Forsaken Kingdom - the puzzles are nice, but hardly brain-teasing or super innovative. I will say that seeing how the world forms and deforms through puzzles solving is really interesting and neat, but like any pretentious indie game, it is never explained how or why parts of buildings can suddenly sprout legs to walk or wings to fly, or why entire towns can be split and connected like a jigsaw puzzle: You're just supposed to "understand" some nebulous meaning and interpret what is going on, like guessing "This is the kid's imagination or how he understand the world works because he is just a kid" or something like that. While it is also clear that this is supposed to be a story about a child and an unclear relationship to his father manifested in a frog eating monster representing an alcohol abusing father, the exposition is all metaphorical and based on the developer's artistic vision, It's less understandable like a good Pixar short or the "Kiwi!" film where you understand the actions and emotions.If you need further proof of what I'm talking about, see the discussion thread about "What does it all mean?!" between players and developers, where the dev doesn't answer the question and instead thanks the players for debating what is going on: http://steamcommunity.com/app/227080/discussions/0/828936718797549690/Papo & Yo gets on my good side for being a short, easy to finish game with a good art style, world design and an overall solid game (fits my Ultra-wide monitor resolution and I had no glitches besides a few graphical glitches early in the game). It gets on my bad side for being another "Guess at what story I'm trying to tell you instead of me actually telling you" arty/farty indie game. The story may strike a cord with other gamers who have experiened child abuse from their parents. This is something playable for children as well, but I doubt they would understand all the real world paralells the game is trying to make, Papo & Yo is essentially an adults game.

Posted: July 9, 2014
												I got this game a long time ago with an Humble Bundle, and finally got around to play it.I'm really really glad that I did. I loved this game, its astounding ambientation, its nice puzzle nature.Let's try to be objective and methodic:-Story: 7/10 The story isn't that great, but it's a break from classic puzzles, it's entertaining enough, and the end packs a punch.-Longevity/Replay value: 4/10 This is the worst part: it takes 3/4 hours to finish it, and once you finish it for the first time, there is really nothing compellingyou to play it again.-Difficulty: 6/10 Pretty much all the puzzles are very straightforward and easy to solve, with the hint box it's even easier. Both on the mental side and the skill required to put it in practice. Failing has no real consequences, as you never really "die" and the worst case scenario is losing a few seconds to respawn, but in the game everything stays as it was, so you don't even have to restart the level. This can be a pro (no frustration) or a con (shorter longevity).-Aesthetic: 10/10 This is the strongest point of the game. The ambientation, some kind of favelas, and the effect that solving the puzzle has on it is simply amazing. It has something mystical mixed with some kind of visual poetry. I greatly enjoyed it. Also kudos to the creators for the cure put into every little detail. Just lovely.-Concept: 9/10 Puzzles that change the conformation of the ambient surrounding you are not really so new, but not that common either.Plus, the implementation is brilliant.-Controls: 7/10 Pretty straightforward. Usual wasd + mouse, third person. The cam is usually fine, in some rare occasion can move awkwardly. But those occasions are very rare, and failing has no big consequences (see "Difficulty")-OST: 8/10 The soundtrack is not, strictly speaking, memorable. But it always fit the game, is easy to the ears, nice, and really helps feeling part of the game.AVG: 7.3It's worth the 11€? I'm not sure. But I'm also pretty stingy.What I can say for sure is that it's worth adding to the wishlist and get on a sale.

Posted: December 20, 2014
												Papo & Yo is short, but powerful; powerful enough that I couldn't write a review immediately after playing it, because it was all still a little too intense.I picked this game up as part of a Humble Bundle, knowing absolutely nothing about it, and installed it when I was in the mood for a bit of indie whimsy.  So it came as a bit of a shock when the opening animation sequence  made it clear that child abuse was going to be a prominent theme of the game -- I had been expecting cheery, light-hearted fluff, and this was looking instead like a terrible downer.  Within a few minutes, however, the setting and gameplay had drawn me in so much that I played all the way through in one sitting, even though I knew the game was writing me a ticket on the feels train.The setting is an appealingly surrealist dreamscape rendition of a South American favela, blending fanciful magic with rusty corrugated iron sheets.  The frequent puzzles are inventive and fun, if not particularly challenging.  But the puzzles aren't the true star of this game; story is the shining star here.   Monster, your companion through most of the game, is a very thinly veiled portrayal of an abusive alcoholic father, and what the game does brilliantly is lead you into the mindset of a victim.  You'll love Monster, fear him, hate him, resent him and even pity him, often at the same time.  You'll find yourself doing ugly, violent things without even thinking about it, because you desperately need to avoid triggering Monster's rage.  You'll make excuses for Monster; you'll blame other things; you'll blame yourself.  You'll allow yourself to believe that you're in control -- that if you just play the game well enough, you can keep Monster content and placid indefinitely.  And, inevitably, it will all come crashing down on you.The majority of "game as art" projects I've seen have been gross, pretentious failures that abandon concepts of gameplay in favour of marching the player on a directed tour through the creator's personal vision, and the interactivity of the experience is reduced to token actions in what is otherwise a sort of animated film or ebook.  Papo & Yo is a high-art game that gets it right; there's a real game here, and it's the gameplay makes it immersive.  Once you've been drawn in through the puzzle game elements, and you really care about the characters and what happens to them, the harsh, wrenching story elements become that much more powerful.Having such mature themes, this game is admittedly not for everyone, but, as far as I'm concerned, it's a masterpiece.

Posted: January 3, 2016
												Papo & Yo is a platform/puzzle game by developers Minority about a Brazilian kid, Quico, and his efforts to live alongside a big and dangerous monster, Papo.Your objective is to guide Quico through the city and paving your own way to the following area each time. In order to do this, you can interact with switches and levers all over the landscape, use your personal toy robot companion (Lula) to activate remote buttons or glide for a short time and, finally, use Papo to your advantage with the right tools. Other sequences from the game revolve instead around fleeing a rampaging Papo and try to calm him down somehow.It's worth mentioning that Papo & Yo is a very short game, being beatable in under four or five hours, but is't nevertheless a very charming game in its own right and something you should consider buying during sales

Posted: January 1, 2016
												I can honestly say Papo & Yo is one of the most amazing games I have ever played.The idea is simple, you're a young lad that has to solve puzzles and challenges using the everchanging surroundings.The gameplay is fairly easy, and everytime it starts to get repetitive something new is added in. However the main reason I'm recommending this game is the incredible storyline behind it.Without spoiling anything, the storyline shows the problems and fears the boy has excellently, even though it never directly mentions it until the ending.All of the characters are unique and easy to understand. For example, the monster can be your best friend, and the next minute he's turning against you.This game grabs you emotionally. After a while you start to connect with the boy and feel how he feels through the parts of the game.Definite recommendation to anyone who wants to waste 4 hours or so (until you play it again).

Posted: October 4, 2013
												Papo & Yo is a quiet game , but it's telling a story contains lots of strong emotions and deep feelings , it needs us to pay a little bit attention to listen and find out . In the begining , everything looked so peaceful , brought me some kind of calmness . As I was going deeper , I couldn't help realizing that Quico has been bearing a lot , that he must protect the ones he loves , help the one who hurts him......that I must help Quico to fix all of this . I think this is the main reason I continued playing . We all make mistakes , grown-up might have a childish immature heart , doing irrational things that only hurt oneself and others , while a little one might have the strongest soul . It doesn't matter how much time that one has been living , what matters the most is that we have the ability to help each other . So I thought the game is about saving an angry monster , and I believed I'd done so . But in the end , I realized there's something beyond salvation . I played as Quico , had to do the final steps by myself , all the conflicts within was about to explode . When it's done , we might understand something .Papo & Yo is a beautiful story , and the story has been being told beautifully . The art is gorgeous in it's own way , very bright and colorful , lighting up the dim raining days , along with the music , creating an exotic world that you want to stay and explore , the ending song is very touching . Lots of elements in the game are symbolic , but it isn't hard to understand , instead , finding out the meaning of these elements by continue playing makes the game more fascinating and engaging . Another thing I love about this game is the level designs . The puzzles are so brilliant and inspiring , you solving them by interacting with the imaginative environment . These two parts are blending in with each other beautifully , for several times I was just "Wow" . But every time the monster was in madness , the whole world was immersed in red color , it felt really uncomfortable . And I admit I'm scared of the mad monster , when I was being chased , I could hardly see myself because the monster was so big . The game is a little bit short though , It only took me 4.6h to finish , but I didn't find all the hats , it might be a glitch because I couldn't wear any of them . Papo and Yo is not a perfect game , but it's beautiful and good enough , I strongly recommend it !!!

Posted: December 18, 2013
												Uttelry beautiful game.The description does not the do the game any justice and is completely misleading. Quico and the monster are not "friends" in the slightest, you are not "playing" with the monster, and you don't "build a friendship" together. The description makes the game sound like a bright, cheerful, Boy and His blob type game. It's not.Watch the launch trailer to get a better feel for what the game is about.*SPOILERS*I don't want to give too much away, but here's the jist:The game is an intriguing and harsh look at alcoholism, anger, neglect, child abuse, and even murder, through the eyes of an innocent child who, being unable to understand these things, creates a fanciful world they can escape to and make sense of them in their own way.The monster altogether ignores you throughout the experience, try as you might to interact with it, like a neglectful parent. When it's not ignoring you, it's eating or sleeping. It only pays you any attention when you have food, or when it is actively trying to harm you. Yes, it "helps" you solve puzzles and progress through the game, but you're not in anyway develping a friendship with the monster.The world is breathtakingly beautiful, with some really innovative and engrossing level design. There's a lot of detail in the mystical favela landscape, and exploring it is equally as enjoyable as the controls are tight and responsive. The game moves very fluidly with excellent pacing and hitting all the right emotional cues. The music is also top notch.Overall, this is a very polished game, and an excellent experience. The whimsical setting and levels juxtapose perfectly with the deeply emotional and dark subject matter. If I had any complaint, it's that the jumping is a little shoddy at times, and since the game has such an emphasis on platforming, that's a bigger deal than it should be. But that doesn't take away from the overall experience.Definitely reccomend it to anyone who likes to play games with a good story, a lot of emotion, and a lot of layers. The fact that the controls are great and the graphics are fantastic is merely icing on this bittersweet yet delectable cake.9/10

Posted: December 20, 2013
												Truly a fantastic adventure game! Papo & Yo will not only present you with interesting puzzles and fun gameplay, but also challenge you to look inward to the demons we all battle throughout life (and more importantly the places we go to escape them).This is a game about a boy named Quico and his seemingly magical action figure Lula, as well as a giant - and normally docile - beast named Monster. As Quico, you will explore various facets of the dream-like favela he escapes to, where the laws of reality itself bend to the whim of one little boy.The core gameplay focuses on solving environmental puzzles, many of which involve magic chalk-like drawings on the walls and floors of buildings that let you manipulate this strange and beautiful world in a variety of different ways. There is also some light platforming and some interesting mechanics which involve Lula, who straddles your backside like a knapsack and acts as a sort of jetpack that can also carry out some basic commands (such as flipping switches for you at a distance). Monster will also play a big part (no pun intended) in solving a lot of said puzzles and offers his own unique mechanics; when he is asleep his massive gut can be used as a trampoline of sorts and of course that brute strength of his also comes in handy! You have to be careful, however, as Monster also has an unhealthy addiction to poisonous frogs which cause him to burst into flames and go on a rampage!All in all this is a refreshing take on 3D puzzle-platformers, that also reminds us just how beautiful and robust the Unreal Engine can still be when in the right hands.

												Y'know, I'm really surprised I haven't heard about this one more. I started playing it after finding it in my library, and found myself coming back to it until the end. It's a fun 3D puzzle platformer, with a thoughtful story, a unique aesthetic, matching soundtrack, stunning environments, and gorgeous artwork. Go try it out! Posted: February 9, 2016
												Anyone who's ever shared a home with an abusive person knows that the management of the aggressor's precarious mental state is key to everyday survival. You're always walking on eggshells, never trusting periods of respite, for you know all too well how little it takes to tip the balance. It's a dangerous tango that, in a morbid way, lends itself rather well to gamification. "Monster", the lumbering, troll-like form the violent father assumes in the child's imagination, must be carefully guided and appeased in order to navigate the game world. It'll have you fooled with its ungainly cuteness, only to erupt into (literally) flaming rage the instant it tastes blood. Make no mistake, this is no game for children. The presentation may be beautiful and the core platforming joyous, but the final act in particular takes a turn for the guttingly sinister. Definite recommendation, but be prepared to be challenged emotionally.

Posted: November 29, 2016
												There are some games that I consider both entertainment and art. Papo and Yo is one of those games. I was researching short games that I could complete in a relatively short amount of time. This game came up during my search, and I happened to own it from a previous Humble Bundle purchase. I decided to install without having any idea what the game was really about  aside from it being a metaphor for the creator's troubled childhood. I found that as I began playing I couldn't put it down, and I didn't exactly know why. This review is a summary of why I believe I kept playing and why you may find yourself wanting to give this game a try:Graphics:Created with the Unreal engine, the game looks good. The graphics aren't amazing in comparison to some other games created with the same engine, but they serve the purpose well and draw you into the South American inspired world.Sound:This is a soundtrack that I would purchase and listen to over and over. You will get lost in the atmospheric tracks as you guide Quico on his journey. Even if you decide not to play the game at least go listen to the music! You won't regret it.Controls:I used an XBOX 360 controller to play. Not much to say here. Controls are simple and the world easy to navigate. There's a basic jump and float mechanic that you will find yourself using throughout most of the game making the game feel somewhat like a 3-D platformer at times.Story:*Minor spoilers ahead*This is where the game's primary focus lies. The game tells a dark tale of a boy and his relationship with his alcoholic father. The story evoked a wide range of emotions from me as I played. I felt myself smiling at times, but there was one moment in particular I remember. It was when the monster ate a frog for the first time, and it evoked some genuine fear and panic in me. I won't say much more than that in order to avoid any major spoilers, but the game does a great job of telling the emotional story that the game's creator set out to tell and bringing you (the player) along for the ride. Puzzles:I made this a category, because this game is technically a puzzle game. I found the puzzles to be fairly simple with only one or two that made me have to give any thought aso to how I would solve them. I was ok with the simplicity, because the game really is more about the story than it is about solving puzzles. However, if you are a player looking for deep puzzles and gameplay, then Papo and Yo may not meet your expectations in these areas.Overall experience:I genuinely enjoyed playing Papo and Yo. While it may not be the type of game that I'd typically find myself playing, I was pleasantly surprised how it drew me in and kept me engaged until the very end. While the story may not be the happiest story, I felt the ending fit the tale well and didn't leave me unsatisfied. The game's soundtrack also delivered, and will be one I listen to periodically when I'm in the mood for a great game soundtrack. The graphics and puzzles aren't the strongest, but they didn't detract from my experience at all. I recommend you give this game a shot! You might end up being just as surprised as I was!TLDR;I recommend you play Papo and Yo for the story and soundtrack, but don't come for the puzzles or any deep gameplay.

Posted: July 27, 2013
												It's a surprisingly affecting story. The monster, Papo, is a metaphor for the alcoholic father of the game's director. But what could have easily been a preachy mess turns out to be an engaging puzzle game with a poignant story. The Brazilian favela makes for an interesting setting, the music is lovely, and the ending actually chocked me up. The only downside is that it's quite short, only about 3-4 hours, but I ended up playing it a second time just because I enjoyed the world and characters so much. Highly recommended.[UPDATE] I just nominated Papo & Yo for the “I'm Not Crying, There's Something In My Eye” Award in this year's Steam Awards. It was a tough choice between this, Gone Home, and Valiant Hearts; but there is something special about Papo & Yo. It touches on a subject that has affected me personally, so it ultimately got my vote. I hope you'll consider it, too.

Posted: October 4, 2013
												Papo & Yo is a quiet game , but it's telling a story contains lots of strong emotions and deep feelings , it needs us to pay a little bit attention to listen and find out . In the begining , everything looked so peaceful , brought me some kind of calmness . As I was going deeper , I couldn't help realizing that Quico has been bearing a lot , that he must protect the ones he loves , help the one who hurts him......that I must help Quico to fix all of this . I think this is the main reason I continued playing . We all make mistakes , grown-up might have a childish immature heart , doing irrational things that only hurt oneself and others , while a little one might have the strongest soul . It doesn't matter how much time that one has been living , what matters the most is that we have the ability to help each other . So I thought the game is about saving an angry monster , and I believed I'd done so . But in the end , I realized there's something beyond salvation . I played as Quico , had to do the final steps by myself , all the conflicts within was about to explode . When it's done , we might understand something .Papo & Yo is a beautiful story , and the story has been being told beautifully . The art is gorgeous in it's own way , very bright and colorful , lighting up the dim raining days , along with the music , creating an exotic world that you want to stay and explore , the ending song is very touching . Lots of elements in the game are symbolic , but it isn't hard to understand , instead , finding out the meaning of these elements by continue playing makes the game more fascinating and engaging . Another thing I love about this game is the level designs . The puzzles are so brilliant and inspiring , you solving them by interacting with the imaginative environment . These two parts are blending in with each other beautifully , for several times I was just "Wow" . But every time the monster was in madness , the whole world was immersed in red color , it felt really uncomfortable . And I admit I'm scared of the mad monster , when I was being chased , I could hardly see myself because the monster was so big . The game is a little bit short though , It only took me 4.6h to finish , but I didn't find all the hats , it might be a glitch because I couldn't wear any of them . Papo and Yo is not a perfect game , but it's beautiful and good enough , I strongly recommend it !!!

												I like exploring & puzzling and Papo & Yo's gameplay reminded me a bit of (old) Tomb Raider although it stays on the easier side (nothing too complex or expansive). There were some nice moments & puzzles I thought were cool and/or surprised me. The end came too sudden, though. I expected a few more devious puzzles as a build up to the finale, but as it turn out, the more "difficult" environments were set halfway to three-quarters of the game.Still, I enjoyed playing this short game very much and I think the developers of the PC port did a good job. Special mentions go to the music near the end of the game, and one of the better ambient occlusion programming I have seen in a game so far.

Posted: February 21
												In what might be a controversial opinion, I didn't love Papo & Yo, but could appreciate its message. Although many of the areas in the environment felt closed off and not conducive to exploration, the puzzle mechanics rose to the surface and succeeded in captivating my attention. Particularly the dream like sequences, and dream-infused interpretations of the character's father, his rebirth in an imaginary monster, were standouts. Papo & Yo approaches narrative excellence with its devastating final message, which will no doubt resonate with anyone who has had similar expereinces. An extremely moving, thought provoking game that masks an inordinate amount of pain. Well done.

Posted: February 21
												Papo & Yo is pretty decent puzzle platformer. It is also a very touching tale about a child dealing with an abusive father.The story is clearly the highlight here. The game deals with a difficult subject matter in an excellent way. Most of the storytelling is done through actual gameplay too instead of long dialogues or endless cutscenes. This is certainly one of the stronger game narratives I have ever experienced.The South American setting, the art style inspired by magical realism and the great soundtrack are all superb fits for the game too.The game does have a number of issues, however. The puzzles and the platforming both tend to be on the easy side and the puzzles in particular feel like an extended tutorial for the actual game that never materializes. The game also suffers from a number of minor glitches and bugs.Despite the somewhat weak gameplay I found Papo & Yo a great and touching experience. I would recommend it to anyone who enjoys good stories.The good:- Superb story- Great storytelling- Fitting art style- Nice soundtrackThe bad:- Rather easy- Little short (I finished the game in little over 3 hours)The ugly:- Quite a few bugs and minor glitches

Posted: February 27, 2016
												Recommended, but only if it's on sale (I think $5 is fair).The game looks very nice and has an awesome fantasy favela setting, but the puzzles are by and large simple and with one single course of action to be taken each time. It's annoying because there are some great ideas set up but they're never combined to make anything challenging. The only time I got stuck was at the very end, when I spent 30 minutes trying to figure out what I was supposed to do before discovering that a scripted event hadn't triggered as it should have.Story-wise, the monster is apparently our friend, but this is only kind of implied because he doesn't object to us bouncing on his stomach while he's asleep; he never actively helps us. He ignores us unless we're bringing him a coconut, and hates us when he eats frogs, until we find him some rotten fruit to calm him down. But even when he's in angry flaming mode he's not much of a threat, just an annoyance. You can't die in this game, so he just throws you around, frustrating your attempts to solve the timed puzzles.With a more engaging story and some more interesting puzzles, or even a co-op mode, this could be something really cool. It's like a long introduction to the game's characters and mechanics, but then once you're starting to get into it, it's all over. I know this review makes it sound like I didn't like it, but I did enjoy playing it. I was just disappointed that by the end it felt like less than the sum of its parts.

Posted: February 20
												Oh man, this game.This game started off as just a fun ride for me. I liked the puzzles a lot, and the gameplay mechanics. I love how you have to change the world around you to continue. Very good.Before getting through the game, I got curious as to what the meaning behind the monster is so I looked up the game and found an interview with the man behind the masterpiece.I've got to say, knowing how he felt, and what he went through made this game a far more emotional experience the entire way through. Maybe it would have felt shocking at the end if I hadn't looked into it first, but knowing the details before really playing it made it hurt me.There were times when I hated the monster, and times when I loved having the monster around. There were times when the girl annoyed me, and pain when she (for reasons I will not spoil) had to leave. The loss of Lula after just getting her back was so painful I started to tear up. This game devastated my emotions, and was a very real experience for me because my brother has a very similar and real problem (again, don't want to spoil it for readers who haven't played) that so far hasn't been remedied, and much like the Quico I've felt like no matter what I do I can't save him.Complimented by a beautiful soundtrack, I really felt this game was one of the best I've ever played, guaranteed. Really recommend playing it if you haven't, and really look forward to games from Minority in the future.

Posted: March 1
												This short puzzle game is an extraordinary example of storytelling through symbolism.  The world exists in the imagination of a child tormented and trying to escape an abusive father with alcoholism.  The powerful symbolic nature of the child needing yet fearing his parent (monster) to progress through the game's (life's) obstacles.The environmental puzzles themselves are usually straightforward. If the player gets stumped, there is a box nearby that will give you hints on how to complete it.  I would recommend using an Xbox 360 or similar controller.5/5 stars

Posted: March 3
												Holy crap.  I was about to give this a thumbs down, but after the ending and the story, I can't possibly do that.  This game gets an A++ in environment graphic design, atmosphere, and story.  However, it gets a major D- (not quite failing but pretty close) in gameplay, puzzle design, and gameplay mechanics.  My favorite thing about this game is the incredibly trippy atmosphere and animations.  Seriously: Think of the Doctor Strange movie, except instead of Benedict Cumberbatch you play as a 10 year old boy, and instead of finding medical help for your hand, in this game you find medical help for your pet monster.The story is simple. You are a boy (quico) who loves two things with all his heart: His pet monster "yo," and his friend robot "lula."  The problem is, Yo is addicted to poisonous frogs, which turn him into a raging fiery demon when he gets them.  The entire story is really cute and happy-go-lucky.  For a while I thought the writers lived in a bubble of happiness and innocence.  But then in the last 10% of the game, it gets dark.  REALLY dark.  I'm talking "Bridge to Terabithia," childhood innocence-turned trauma status.  And not just because of violence or mature themes.  No, I mean this tackles a very real and serious social issue that ruins the lives of millions throughout the world.  You can't see it coming for a while, but when you realize the true "innocence lost" at the ending, it's incredibly harrowing.  I started tearing up.  For anyone who wants to spoil it, the social truth behind the game is:  This game is one big metaphor for kids with violently abusive and alcoholic parents.  The graphics, by the way, are top-notch, for 2013 and even for 2017.  It takes place in a south american favela-style environment.  The sunshine, shadow, and texturing effects look stunning.  There's one major flaw with the game, and that's the actual gameplay.  This game really doesn't have any puzzles whatsoever.  It's mainly just "see something that looks weird, go up to it, notice it moves a platform, jump on that platform and repeat."  I think there might have only been one or two times where I actually had to think about what to do and comprehend the situation, which should be a given for every single puzzle in any adequate puzzle game.  They're bland and straightforward.  There even came a point near the end of the game where the solutions *LITERALLY* showed up directly in front of your character as they arose.  That's ridiculous.  The game and its controls run very fluidly, but your movement sometimes feel stiff due to its seeming exception from the laws of physics.  Parkour-esque movement would have been KEY to this game, but it felt more like a literal platform-hopping game.  In conclusion, lemme repeat my original grading:Story: A+Environment: A+Atmosphere: APuzzles: FGameplay: DGraphics: B++For 15$, I'm shrugging.  It's definitely not worth the money, but I don't think it would disappoint that badly.  I got the game in a massive humble bundle, so it was somewhat free for me (though not technically), so I am not complaining either way.  It took me nearly 4 hours to beat, which is definitely on the much shorter end as others have complained, but I'd say 4 hours is hearty enough for me to feel a little disappointed; but not shocked or ripped off.  It's an "ok" value for the content.However, if you're one for emotionally gripping stories and innocence-lost narratives (I feel like the vibe of Bridge to Terabithia is actually a very accurate analogy to the emotions I got from this game), this is an absolute golden nugget.

												The platforming was just how I like it; impressively responsive and not relying on testing how finicky you can be in testing its parameters but instead putting you in environments that test your nerves instead.The story was very delicately told and Papo and Yo is far from a Super Mario game in its setting; exchanging cute and colourful for natural tones, abstract, moody and cinematic its very Alice in Wonder Land at times with loads of resonating character it all very surreal. There are some adorable moments; your interaction with chubby big eyed frogs, the hint boxes were the best execution I have seen for giving a hint to players in game, and the characters themselves have much more depth than I am used in any video game.Papo and Yo is strikingly original at times and if there is one thing the majority of its reviews agree on its that Papo and Yo's strongest point is its a charming and eloquently told story that is of something the medium desperately needs: something to contemplate and something human.

												Papo & Yo is pretty decent puzzle platformer. It is also a very touching tale about a child dealing with an abusive father.The story is clearly the highlight here. The game deals with a difficult subject matter in an excellent way. Most of the storytelling is done through actual gameplay too instead of long dialogues or endless cutscenes. This is certainly one of the stronger game narratives I have ever experienced.The South American setting, the art style inspired by magical realism and the great soundtrack are all superb fits for the game too.The game does have a number of issues, however. The puzzles and the platforming both tend to be on the easy side and the puzzles in particular feel like an extended tutorial for the actual game that never materializes. The game also suffers from a number of minor glitches and bugs.Despite the somewhat weak gameplay I found Papo & Yo a great and touching experience. I would recommend it to anyone who enjoys good stories.The good:- Superb story- Great storytelling- Fitting art style- Nice soundtrackThe bad:- Rather easy- Little short (I finished the game in little over 3 hours)The ugly:- Quite a few bugs and minor glitches

Posted: April 9
												The platforming was just how I like it; impressively responsive and not relying on testing how finicky you can be in testing its parameters but instead putting you in environments that test your nerves instead.The story was very delicately told and Papo and Yo is far from a Super Mario game in its setting; exchanging cute and colourful for natural tones, abstract, moody and cinematic its very Alice in Wonder Land at times with loads of resonating character it all very surreal. There are some adorable moments; your interaction with chubby big eyed frogs, the hint boxes were the best execution I have seen for giving a hint to players in game, and the characters themselves have much more depth than I am used in any video game.Papo and Yo is strikingly original at times and if there is one thing the majority of its reviews agree on its that Papo and Yo's strongest point is its a charming and eloquently told story that is of something the medium desperately needs: something to contemplate and something human.

Posted: February 20
												Oh man, this game.This game started off as just a fun ride for me. I liked the puzzles a lot, and the gameplay mechanics. I love how you have to change the world around you to continue. Very good.Before getting through the game, I got curious as to what the meaning behind the monster is so I looked up the game and found an interview with the man behind the masterpiece.I've got to say, knowing how he felt, and what he went through made this game a far more emotional experience the entire way through. Maybe it would have felt shocking at the end if I hadn't looked into it first, but knowing the details before really playing it made it hurt me.There were times when I hated the monster, and times when I loved having the monster around. There were times when the girl annoyed me, and pain when she (for reasons I will not spoil) had to leave. The loss of Lula after just getting her back was so painful I started to tear up. This game devastated my emotions, and was a very real experience for me because my brother has a very similar and real problem (again, don't want to spoil it for readers who haven't played) that so far hasn't been remedied, and much like the Quico I've felt like no matter what I do I can't save him.Complimented by a beautiful soundtrack, I really felt this game was one of the best I've ever played, guaranteed. Really recommend playing it if you haven't, and really look forward to games from Minority in the future.
